THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Terry Cartrette Tindall,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
H&S Homes, LLC, d/b/a Horton Homes of Conway; and Pete Hughes, Jr., Individually and as an Agent for H&S Homes, LLC, d/b/a Horton Homes of Conway, Horton Homes, Inc., and Bombardier Capital, Inc.,       
Defendants,
Of Whom, H&S Homes, LLC is,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-535
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed October 3, 2003Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Boone Aiken, III, of Florence, and James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Peter L. Hearn, Sr, of Conway, and Richard M. Lovelace, Jr., of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Terry Tindall brought this action against H&S Homes, LLC, Pete Hughes, Jr., and Horton Homes, Inc. for breach of contract, fraud, negligence, and breach of express and implied warranty.Â  The jury awarded Tindall actual and punitive damages on her negligence cause of action against H&S.Â  H&S appeals, arguing the trial court should have granted its motions for directed verdict, JNOV, and a new trial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Horton Homes, Inc., of Edenton Georgia, is a mobile home manufacturer that principally owns and operates approximately thirty mobile home dealerships in the Southeast.Â  H&S Homes, LLC, of Conway, is a Horton Homes dealership.Â  Pete Hughes, Jr., began working as H&Sâ€™s general manager in September of 1998.Â  Hughes testified that H&S received a damaged 1997 model mobile home some time prior to the time he began his employment.
Terry Tindall is a disabled and dyslexic forty-four-year-old single mother with minimal education.Â  In March of 1999, Tindall and her teenage daughter visited H&S Homes on several occasions to purchase a double-wide mobile home.Â  Hughes showed Tindall several homes, including the damaged 1997 model, which Tindall alleges Hughes told her was a 1998 model.Â  On March 5, 1999, Tindall signed a purchase agreement to buy the alleged 1998 model home for $53,210.Â  The purchase agreement did not include the model year, but it did indicate the home was new.
H&S allowed Tindall and her
daughter to move into the home prior to the April 16, 1999 closing.Â  During the closing, Tindall learned the home was a 1997 model.Â  The closing attorney delayed the closing in response to Tindallâ€™s concern regarding the model year, but Tindall completed the purchase because H&S sold her trade-in, a single-wide mobile home, and the purchaser of the trade-in had already moved in to the home prior to the closing.Â  Tindall testified she felt â€œstuckâ€ because â€œshe didnâ€™t have anywhere to go.â€
Tindallâ€™s neighbor testified the walls â€œlooked like somebody took a hammer and just beat holes in it.â€Â  The home leaked around the windows, under the sinks, behind the refrigerator, and in the bathrooms.Â  As a result, the exterior walls, floors, and cabinets rotted and the vinyl floor became discolored.Â  The leaks also created mold and mildew, resulting in a bad odor throughout the home.Â  The commode was replaced three times, the doors were unlevel and would not close properly, and the molding around the front door was three quarters of an inch off the wall.Â  A carpenter hired by Tindall testified the molding was â€œnot even touching the wall to seal the draft . . . around the doorway.â€Â  The ceiling fan fell out of the ceiling, and the chandelier was damaged to the extent it had to be taken apart and put back together.Â  Tindall testified the linoleum in the bathroom, kitchen, and her daughterâ€™s room had â€œcuts in itâ€ from when H&S â€œset the house up.â€Â  Tindall also testified the kitchen â€œsmell[ed] like sewerâ€ and when she hired a plumber to determine the cause of the smell, the plumber found one of the plumbing vents did not have a vent cap to prevent the sewer gas from backing up the line.Â  Additionally, the brick underpinning on the house was falling down because there was not enough mortar in the brickwork.Â  Incidentally, a neighbor witnessed H&Sâ€™s work crew drinking liquor as the crew set up Tindallâ€™s brick underpinning. 
Tindall contacted H&S on several occasions asking H&S to repair her home.Â  H&S attempted to repair some of the problems, but many of the repairs were unsuccessful or inadequate.Â  Tindall testified concerning several of H&Sâ€™s attempts to repair including the following:Â  (1) H&S tried to fix the leak under the bathroom sink, â€œbut when they would come out they would . . . screw that little screw . . . where the sink is and it would split all the way up, so it kept leakingâ€; (2) H&S replaced the first commode and â€œtried to put caulking on it, silicon, to stop it from leaking, and it leaked around the commode pipes, and it turned the floor darkâ€;Â  (3) H&S put clear caulking on the ceiling cracks, but the clear caulking could not be painted; (4) H&S replaced the back door because of water damage, but did not attempt to repair the leak that caused the damage; (5) H&S attempted to repair the doors, but the doors remained unlevel and never shut properly; (6) H&S patched the torn linoleum floors in the kitchen, bathroom, and bedroom with silicone instead of replacing the floors with vinyl; and (7) H&S placed screws in the bottoms of leaking windows, but the screws blocked the weep holes, prevented drainage, and caused the windows to rust out.Â  H&S did not even attempt to repair several of the problems, including repair or replacement of furniture that was damaged during the transport of the home.
Tindall brought this action against H&S Homes, Horton Homes, and Pete Hughes, Jr., for negligence, fraud, breach of contract, and breach of express and implied warranty.Â  At trial, the defendants moved for a directed verdict on all causes of action.Â  The trial judge granted the motion for negligence as to Horton Homes, but denied the motion on all grounds as to H&S Homes.Â  At the close of the testimony, the defendants renewed the motions.Â  Following the motions, the court conducted a charge conference.Â  During the conference, the trial judge determined the jury could choose only one theory of liability.Â  Tindall elected to forgo the warranty causes of action to â€œsimplify matters for the jury.â€Â  The court, therefore, instructed the jury on the following causes of action: (1) breach of contract as to H&S Homes and Horton Homes; (2) fraud and deceit as to H&S Homes and Pete Hughes, Jr.; and (3) negligence as to H&S Homes.Â  In addition, the court submitted the issue of punitive damages to the jury on the theory of fraud and deceit and on the theory of negligence.
The jury found for the defendants on the breach of contract action and on the fraud and deceit action. Â The jury found for Tindall on the theory of negligence.Â  The jury awarded $95,000 actual damages and $300,000 punitive damages.Â  H&S Homes moved for a new trial, a new trial nisi remittitur, and a JNOV.Â  The trial judge granted the nisi remittitur, reduced the verdict for actual damages to $43,210, and directed Tindallâ€™s counsel to notify the court within ten days whether Tindall would accept the reduced verdict.Â  The trial judge indicated if Tindall refused to accept the new verdict, the trial judge would grant a new trial absolute.
H&S Homes moved to strike the punitive damages award arguing, â€œwhat the jury had the opportunity to find here was ordinary negligence and ordinary negligence in this state will not support a punitive damage award.â€Â  The trial judge responded that he would review the punitive damage award if Tindall accepted the new trial nisi remittitur.Â  Tindall accepted the new trial nisi remittitur within the ten-day time limit, and the judge entered his order of judgment in the reduced amount.Â  The parties then submitted briefs to the trial judge on the issue of punitive damages.Â  After conducting a review pursuant to Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 350 (1991), the judge declined to reduce the amount of the punitive damages award in a June 28, 2004 order.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ ANALYSIS
I.Â  Directed Verdict and JNOV
H&S argues the trial court erred by denying its motions for directed verdict and JNOV because there was no evidence that H&S negligently breached any tort duty owed to Tindall.Â  This argument is not preserved for review.
On appeal, H&S alleges that Tindall was attempting to convert an action for breach of warranty and for fraud, both contract actions, into a negligence action, a tort action.[1]Â  However, at trial, H&S did not assert that Tindall was trying to convert a contract action into a tort.Â  In its motion for directed verdict, H&S simply argued that Tindallâ€™s negligence allegation was not supported by evidence as pled:

[Tindallâ€™s] allegations are that Horton, H&S LLC was willfully negligent in the transportation, installation of the home violating applicable housing standards for such transportation and installation.Â  I donâ€™t believe thereâ€™s been any evidence about what standards for transportation [and] installation there are, if there happen to be such standards.Â  There just hasnâ€™t been any evidence in this case and Iâ€™m just saying that the negligence count not only falls with regard to Horton Homes[,] it also falls as pled with regard to H&S. 

Therefore, H&Sâ€™s motion for a directed verdict was not sufficient to preserve the issue on appeal.Â  See State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (stating a party cannot argue one theory at trial and a different theory on appeal); State v. Fletcher,  363 S.C. 221, 257, 609 S.E.2d 572, 591 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œTo be preserved for appellate review, an objection should be sufficiently specific to bring into focus the precise nature of the alleged error.â€).
II.Â  New Trial Absolute
H&S argues the trial judge erred by not granting a new trial absolute because the verdict for actual damages exceeded the largest amount supported by the evidence.Â  We disagree.
â€œIf the amount of the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive so as to be the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, or some other influence outside the evidence, the trial judge must grant a new trial absolute.â€ Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 527, 431 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1993).Â  Also, if the verdict â€œconclusively shows the jury disregarded the courtâ€™s instructions or else capriciously fixed damages without reference to the evidence,â€ then it is error for the court to refuse a motion for new trial.Â  Carrigg v. Blue, 283 S.C. 494, 500, 323 S.E.2d 787, 790 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s failure to grant a new trial absolute in such situations amounts to an abuse of discretion and on appeal this court will grant a new trial absolute.Â  Weir v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs. Inc., 312 S.C. 511, 518, 435 S.E.2d 864, 868-69 (1993).
In this case, Tindall paid $53,210 and traded in a single-wide mobile home valued at $8,100 to purchase the mobile home from H&S.Â  Additionally, the record contains testimony that the cost to repair the home would exceed the value of the home.Â  Taking all of these factors into consideration, we find that the juryâ€™s verdict of $95,000 in actual damages was not grossly excessive so as to be the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, or some other influence outside the evidence.Â  
Furthermore, H&S moved for a new trial nisi remittitur in addition to moving for a new trial absolute, which the court granted.Â  â€œ[T]he import of a new trial nisi additur or nisi remittitur is a suggestion on the part of the [trial] judge of a settlement figure.â€ Stroud v. Stroud, 299 S.C. 394, 397, 385 S.E.2d 205, 206 (Ct. App. 1989) (overruled on other grounds).Â  â€œThe trial court has wide discretionary power to reduce the amount of a verdict which in his or her judgment is excessive.â€Â  Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 381, 426 S.E.2d 802, 805 (1993).Â  On appeal, the trial judgeâ€™s decision â€œto reduce the verdict will not be disturbed unless it clearly appears that the exercise of discretion was controlled by a manifest error of law.â€Â  Id.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s decision is given great deference because the judge, â€œwho heard the evidence and is more familiar with the evidentiary atmosphere at trial[,] possesses a better-informed view of the damages than this [c]ourt.â€Â  Id.Â  
Additionally, if the party opposing the motion for a new trial nisi remittitur agrees to pay the amount suggested by the trial court, the opposing party cannot thereafter complain.Â  Stroud, 299 S.C. at 397, 385 S.E.2d at 206.Â  â€œHaving asked for the relief and having received it, the moving party is likewise bound.â€Â  Estes v. Grav,  319 S.C. 551, 554, 462 S.E.2d 561, 562 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Because H&S moved for the remittitur and received it, H&S is bound by the judgment.Â  

    III.Â  Punitive DamagesÂ  
H&S argues the trial judge erred by submitting the issue of punitive damages to the jury because there was no evidence that its conduct was reckless, willful, or wanton.Â  We disagree.
The issue of punitive damages must be submitted to the jury if more than one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence as to whether the defendantâ€™s behavior was reckless, willful, or wanton.Â  Graham v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 393, 398, 321 S.E.2d 40, 43 (1984).Â  To receive punitive damages, the plaintiff has the burden of proving by clear and convincing evidence that the defendantâ€™s misconduct was willful, wanton, or in reckless disregard of the plaintiffâ€™s rights.Â  Scott v. Porter, 340 S.C. 158, 172, 530 S.E.2d 389, 396 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œA conscious failure to exercise due care constitutes willfulness.â€Â  Hawkins v. Pathology Assocs. of Greenville, P.A.,  330 S.C. 92, 110, 498 S.E.2d 395, 405 (Ct. App. 1998). A tort is reckless, willful, or wanton if committed in such a manner or under such circumstances that an ordinary person would have been conscious of it as an invasion of the plaintiffâ€™s rights.Â  Id.Â  Although an award of punitive damages demands more than gross negligence, â€œnegligence may be so gross as to amount to recklessness, and when it does, it ceases to be mere negligence and assumes very much the nature of willfulness.â€Â  Hicks v. McCandlish,  221 S.C. 410, 415, 70 S.E.2d 629, 631 (1952).Â  
Tindall presented evidence that could be interpreted as reckless, willful, and wanton conduct by H&S.Â  There was testimony that H&S â€œthrewâ€ siding in the mobile home during its transport, tearing furniture and destroying the interior walls, H&Sâ€™s work crew drank liquor as they set up the brick underpinning of Tindallâ€™s home, and H&S sent Tindall a box of hinges rather than fix the doors.Â  Thus, the trial judge did not err in submitting the issue of punitive damages to the jury.
AFFIRMED. 
BEATTY, SHORT, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur. 

[1]  Although H&S did not mention the â€œeconomic loss ruleâ€ in its brief, it is essentially what they are arguing.Â  The economic loss rule assists in determining whether contract or tort theories are applicable to a given case.Â  Kennedy v. Columbia Lumber & Mfg. Co., Inc., 299 S.C. 335, 345, 384 S.E.2d 730, 736 (1989).Â  While some states have used the economic loss rule to prohibit tort actions for purely economic damages, South Carolina has recognized limited tort actions where the damages were purely economic losses.Â  Id. at 346, 384 S.E.2d at 737 (holding that a cause of action in negligence will be available where a builder has violated a legal duty, no matter the type of resulting damage); Beachwalk Villas Condo. Assâ€™n, Inc. v. Martin, 305 S.C. 144, 147, 406 S.E.2d 372, 374 (1991) (extending the Kennedy decision to architects).Â  Our supreme court has determined that the question of whether the plaintiff may maintain an action in tort for purely economic loss turns on the determination of the source of the duty plaintiff claims the defendant owed.Â  The court held that a plaintiff might maintain an action in tort for purely economic loss if the breach of duty arises independently of any contract duties.Â  Tommy L. Griffin Plumbing & Heating Co. v. Jordan, Jones & Goulding, Inc., 320 S.C. 49, 55, 463 S.E.2d 85, 89 (1995) (holding that design professionals can be liable in tort for purely economic loss when the relationship between the design professional and the plaintiff is such that the design professional owes a professional duty to the plaintiff arising separate and distinct from any contractual duties between the parties or with third parties).Â  However, â€œ[a] breach of duty which arises under the provisions of a contract between the parties must be redressed under contract, and a tort action will not lie.â€Â  Tommy L. Griffin Plumbing & Heating Co., 320 S.C. at 56, 463 S.E.2d at 88.

Robert A. Muckenfuss, of Charlotte, for Appellant.
Emma Ruth Brittain, of Myrtle Beach, John L. Weaver, Office of the Horry County Attorney, of Conway, Mark Andrew Brunty, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Sun Publishing appeals the denial of its request for attorney fees as the prevailing party in an action brought pursuant to the South Carolina Freedom of Information Act (â€œFOIAâ€).[1]Â  Sun Publishing maintains the circuit court abused its discretion by failing to enter any findings of fact regarding the denial of its fee request. Â We agree. 
If a person or entity seeking relief prevails in an action brought pursuant to the FOIA, reasonable attorney fees and other costs of litigation may be awarded.[2] Â The circuit courtâ€™s order denying attorney fees in this case states the request was denied â€œ[b]ased upon the facts of this case.â€Â  The circuit court included no explanation of what those facts were, notwithstanding Sun Publishing in its application for attorney fees cited Burton v. York County Sheriffâ€™s Department[3] and quoted the portion of Burton that referenced a trial courtâ€™s duty to â€œmake specific findings of fact on the recordâ€ when determining an award of attorney fees.[4]Â  A failure to enter findings regarding the denial of a request for attorney fees under the FOIA is an abuse of discretion and warrants remand for proper consideration.[5] Â We therefore remand this matter to the circuit court pursuant to Burton for it to make specific findings of fact on the record regarding Sun Publishingâ€™s right to attorney fees.Â  
REMANDED. [6]
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 30-4-10 to -165 (1991 & Supp. 2004).
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-100(b) (1991); Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist.,
354 S.C. 274, 288-89, 580 S.E.2d 163, 170 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding the circuit court has discretion to award attorney fees where a party prevails in a claim for information under the FOIA).
[3] 358 S.C. 339, 594 S.E.2d 888 (Ct. App. 2004).
[4] Id. at 358, 594 S.E.2d at 898. 
[5] Id. at 357, 594 S.E.2d at 898 (holding the trial courtâ€™s failure to enter findings regarding the denial of a request for attorney fees under the FOIA was an abuse of discretion and warranted remand for proper consideration).
[6]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM: Albert Scruggs appeals his conviction for assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct in the first degree.Â  Scruggs argues the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because the indictment was materially amended after it was true-billed by the grand jury.Â  Upon remand by the court of appeals, the circuit court made a factual determination that the indictment had been re-presented in its amended form to the grand jury prior to Scruggâ€™s trial.[1]Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities: State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005) (holding that presentment of an indictment is not needed to confer subject matter jurisdiction, but an indictment is needed to give notice to the defendant of the charge against him); Evans v. State, 363 S.C. 495, 508, 611 S.E.2d 510, 517 (2005) (â€œThe primary purposes of an indictment are .Â  .Â  . to apprise [the defendant] of the elements of the offense and to allow [the defendant] to decide whether to plead guilty or stand trial, and to enable the circuit court to know what judgment to pronounce if the defendant is convicted.â€).
AFFIRMED. [2]
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur. 

[1] Appellant concedes in his supplemental final brief that there is no longer an issue regarding the indictment.
[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James Michael Tharington, Respondent,
v.
Elizabeth Votor, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
H. T. Abbott, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-539
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 11, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Anita Ruth Floyd, Â of Conway, for Appellant.
Frederick L. Harris, of Surfside Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â In this appeal from a decree of divorce, Elizabeth Votor argues the family court erred in 1) refusing to hold the husband, James Michael Tharington, in contempt, 2) changing the surname of the partiesâ€™ child from Votor to Tharington, and 3) awarding Votor only $2500.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.Â  1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Tharington and Votor were married on July 25, 2001.Â  Votor was pregnant with their child at the time.Â  The parties had a heated argument on their honeymoon and their relationship never recovered.Â  During the marriage Tharington spent two to three weeks a month in Tennessee on business.Â  He left for one such trip the day before the partiesâ€™ child was born.Â  Once he arrived at the hospital after the child was born by caesarian section, he stayed for thirty minutes.Â  Tharington did not return to the hospital during Votorâ€™s five-day hospital stay until the day Votor and the child were to be discharged.Â  When he arrived at the hospital, Tharington learned that Votor had named their son Aidan John Votor rather than giving the child his surname.Â  He and Votor argued until she asked hospital personnel to make Tharington leave.Â  Tharington then left the hospital without Votor or Aidan.Â  Votor had to call Tharingtonâ€™s mother and ask her to bring them home.Â  The partiesâ€™ separated on January 14, 2002, ten days after their sonâ€™s birth.Â  
On February 25, 2002, the parties were involved in an altercation at the marital home.Â  Votor called 9-1-1.Â  The responding officer, Corporal Dan Flood, testified that the partiesâ€™ gave conflicting stories about how a scratch on Votorâ€™s arm occurred.Â  Votor stated Tharington had pushed her, causing her to fall over a trash bag and hit her arm on the wall, but Tharington stated Votor had merely tripped over the bag and fallen.Â  Corporal Flood testified he did not believe he had probable cause to make an arrest.Â  He stayed at the residence until Tharington, who had offered to leave, packed up his belongings and left.Â  
Votor filed with the family court a petition for an order of protection on February 27, 2002.Â  The parties entered into a consent order providing inter alia that Votor would be entitled to the marital home until the house she owned could be refurbished and that Tharington would be responsible for the cost of refurbishing the house.Â  Votor was to vacate the marital home upon 48 hours notice by Tharington that the refurbishment was complete.Â  
Tharington filed a petition for a rule to show cause on March 13, 2002 asserting Votor should be held in contempt for failing to vacate the marital home in accordance with the consent order.Â  The family court declined to hold Votor in contempt.Â  
In the meantime, Tharington had filed a complaint for an order of separate maintenance.Â  He asked for joint custody of Aidan, child support, and possession of the marital home.Â  Votor filed a counterclaim seeking a divorce on the grounds of adultery and physical cruelty, sole custody of Aidan, equitable distribution of debt, possession of the marital home, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Votor left the marital home to return to her own house.Â  Once there, she replaced the carpets, had new appliances installed, and took other steps to improve the home.Â  At the final hearing, she sought to have Tharington held responsible for these improvements under the consent order.Â  
In the final decree of divorce, the family court granted the parties a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation, awarded Votor custody of Aidan and standard visitation to Tharington, and set child support.Â  At Tharingtonâ€™s request, the family court ordered Aidanâ€™s birth certificate be amended to read â€œAidan John Tharington.â€Â  The court held Tharington was not responsible for the funds Votor expended improving her home.Â  It also made other rulings on the equitable distribution of the marital estate and debt.Â  Finally, the court ordered Tharington to be responsible for $2500.00 of Votorâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Both parties filed motions to alter or amend.Â  The family court clarified visitation and changed its ruling to provide Tharington must reimburse Votor for the tires she purchased for his vehicle.Â  Other than those rulings, the court reaffirmed its previous rulings.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEWÂ Â  
â€œOn appeal from an order of the family court, this court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 304, 540 S.E.2d 454, 456 (2000).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to ignore the findings of the family court.Â  Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 58, 552 S.E.2d 329, 334 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œNeither are we required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€ Id.
DISCUSSION
1.     Contempt
Votor argues the family court erred when it declined to hold Tharington in contempt for failing to comply with the consent order that he would refurbish her house.Â  We disagree.Â  
A determination of contempt lies within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck Stop, Inc. v. Cloyd, 350 S.C. 596, 607, 567 S.E.2d 514, 519 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œA determination of contempt is a serious matter and should be imposed sparingly.â€Â  Haselwood v. Sullivan, 283 S.C. 29, 32, 320 S.E.2d 499, 501 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Contempt results from willful disobedience of a court order.Â  Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck Stop, Inc., 350 S.C. at 607, 567 S.E.2d at 519.Â  In order for a person to be held in contempt, the record must be clear and specific as to acts or conduct upon which the contempt is based.Â  Id.Â  A willful act is â€œone done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€Â  Id. at 608, 567 S.E.2d at 520. 
During the partiesâ€™ marriage, Votor rented out the house in which she had lived before the marriage.Â  The tenants vacated the house around the time of the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  In the March 5, 2002 consent order, the parties agreed:

[Votor] is entitled to the marital [home] as to such time the non-marital home can be refurbished.Â  At the time the home is refurbished [Votor] will have 48 [hours] notice by [Tharington] and she will depart the marital home.Â  [Tharington] is responsible for the costs associated with the refurbished home.Â  

Tharington testified he had the walls of Votorâ€™s house painted and had the carpets professionally steam cleaned.Â  Tharington repaired holes in the sheetrock, a broken glass door in the medicine cabinet, and the broken door on the bathroom vanity, and replaced doorknobs.Â  He also installed a washer and dryer himself.Â  Tharington acknowledged that he had agreed to replace the carpets if needed, but insisted the carpets â€œcleaned up fine.â€Â  In addition, he testified that all of the appliances worked.Â  
Votor testified she wanted Tharington to replace the carpet because her tenantsâ€™ dogs had urinated on them.Â  She stated the pet stains on the carpet quickly reappeared.Â  She purchased new carpet herself and had it installed.Â  She also purchased and had installed new appliances including a refrigerator, dishwasher, stove, and washer.Â  She had a microwave installed over the stove and new shelves installed in the closet.Â  She and her friends repainted the inside of the house.Â  Votor also presented her bills for having cable and utilities hooked up to her house and for $4900.00 in furniture.Â  She asked the court to hold Tharington responsible for these expenses under the consent order.Â  
The court, however held it would not â€œbe appropriate to make any award for [Tharington] to pay [Votor] as to the alleged costs.Â  To do so would require an interpretation of the term â€˜refurbishmentâ€™ and the testimony presented is insufficient to establish that the parties intended for [Tharington] to make such major improvements to [Votorâ€™s] home.â€Â  
We find no abuse of discretion in this ruling.Â  Tharington testified that he had completed the â€œrefurbishmentâ€ as required by the consent order while Votor testified his work was incomplete.Â  Although the partiesâ€™ testimony is contradictory, we find the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s holding that Tharington should not be held responsible for the extensive improvements Votor made to her house.Â  
Votor asserts that when the family court declined to hold her in contempt on Tharingtonâ€™s rule to show cause, it tacitly held that Tharington had not completed the refurbishment in accordance with the partiesâ€™ agreement.Â  However, at the hearing on the rule, the family court explained that it was declining to hold Votor in contempt because there had been no â€œmeeting of the mindsâ€ and the parties were not in agreement as to what the word â€œrefurbishâ€ meant.Â  This finding in no way supports Votorâ€™s contention that Tharington should be held in contempt.Â  Rather, the family court declined to hold either party in contempt of the order because, as there was no agreement between the parties, neither party was acting in willful disobedience of the order.
Accordingly, we find the family court did not err in declining to hold Tharington in contempt and refusing to make Tharington responsible for the funds Votor expended improving her house.Â Â Â  
2.     Name change
Votor argues the family court erred in ordering the partiesâ€™ sonâ€™s name be changed from Aidan John Votor to Aidan John Tharington.Â  We disagree.Â  
Votor contends the family court did not have authority to grant the name change because Tharington never requested such relief in his pleading.Â  As Votor failed to raise this issue to the family court, it is not preserved for our review.Â  SeeÂ  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â Â  
The family court should grant a request to change a childâ€™s surname only if the change promotes the childâ€™s best interests and welfare.Â  Mazzone v. Miles, 341 S.C. 203, 210, 532 S.E.2d 890, 893 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The burden of proving that the change will further the childâ€™s best interests lies on the parent seeking to change the childâ€™s surname.Â  Id.Â  Both parents have an equal interest in the child bearing their respective surname.Â  Id. at 211-12, 532 S.E.2d at 894.
In Mazzone, this court set out the following factors for the court to consider in a request for childâ€™s name to be changed:Â  

(1) The length of time that the child has used the present surname; (2) the effect of the change on the preservation and development of the childâ€™s relationship with each parent; (3) the identification of the child as part of a family unit; (4) the wishes of the parents; (5) the stated reason for the proposed change; (6) the motive of the parents and the possibility that the use of a different name will cause insecurity or a lack of identity; (7) the difficulty, harassment, or embarrassment that the child may experience when the child bears a surname different from the custodial parent; (8) theÂ  preference of the child if the child is of an age and maturity to express a meaningful preference; and (9) the degree of community respect associated with the present and proposed surname.Â Â  

Id. at 210-11, 532 S.E.2d at 893-94. 
Applying the above factors that are applicable in this case, we find the change of Aidanâ€™s surname to Tharington is in his best interest.Â  Aidan was barely two years old at the time the family court ordered the change of his surname.Â  It is unlikely he had developed a strong identification with the surname Votor at such a young age.Â  There is no indication in the record that the change of Aidanâ€™s last name to Tharington would weaken his relationship with Votor, who appears to be a devoted mother.Â  Tharington also appears to be an involved parent, exercising the visitation awarded to him and requesting more.Â  Although Tharingtonâ€™s relationship with Aidan would probably not be damaged by Aidan retaining the name Votor, the change to Tharington may even strengthen the bond between father and son.Â  
For the third factor, identification as a family unit, we find no preference in name.Â  Votor does have a daughter from a previous relationship, but as this child has the surname of her father, she and Aidan would have different surnames even if Aidan had the name Votor.Â  
As to the wishes of the parents, it is obvious both want Aidan to bear his or her own surname.Â  Next, we consider the partiesâ€™ motives.Â  Tharington testified the reason he married Votor was for his son and that it was very important to him for his son to have his last name.Â  There is evidence in the record that although Votor never changed her name on her social security card or driverâ€™s license, she did in fact use the name Tharington.Â  She changed her name to Tharington for her banking and checked into the hospital under the name Tharington when she delivered Aidan.Â  The hospital bills and records list Aidan as â€œBaby Boy Tharington.â€Â  Thus, the record indicates Tharington asked for the change in keeping with the partiesâ€™ understanding of what the childâ€™s name would be.
Votor testified that she gave Aidan her surname because by the time she named him, she knew she was going to be a single parent and she did not want to have three different last names in her household.Â  However, Votorâ€™s attorney gave another motive for the name in a letter dated March 20, 2002, writing:Â  â€œIn a moment of frustration and anger, Ms. Votor did not give Aidan Mr. Tharingtonâ€™s last name but instead used her name.Â  This was because Mr. Tharington was in Tennessee with a paramour throughout the Christmas holidays as well as at the time of the birth of the partiesâ€™ child.â€Â  
Considering the letter, the family court found Votorâ€™s explanation for giving Aidan her surname was â€œdisingenuous at best.â€Â  The evidence shows a great deal of animosity between the parties at the time of Aidanâ€™s birth and Votorâ€™s decision on his name.Â  On the day before Aidan was born, Tharington left for Tennessee on business, planning to return for the scheduled caesarian section on the following Monday.Â  Votor testified she begged him not to leave because she believed the baby would be born earlier.Â  Tharington did not return before Votor underwent an emergency cesarian section the next day.Â  Tharington came to the hospital that day, but left thirty minutes later after he and Votor had an argument.Â  He did not return during Votor and Aidanâ€™s five-day hospital stay until the day they were to be discharged.Â  Votor testified that it was not until this fifth day she decided to give Aidan the last name Votor.Â Â Â Â  
We agree with the family court, which was in a better position to judge Votorâ€™s credibility, that her explanation for the naming was disingenous and her actual motive was anger and frustration with Tharington, as stated in her attorneyâ€™s letter. 
Tharington testified that Votorâ€™s giving the child her surname has been a â€œbone of contentionâ€ since he found out about it.Â  The change of Aidanâ€™s name to Tharington in accordance with what appears to have been the intention of the parties during the pregnancy may in fact alleviate some of the animosity between the parties.Â Â  
The final applicable factor is the difficulty, harassment, or embarrassment that the child may experience when the child bears a surname different from the custodial parent.Â  Votor currently is the custodial parent.Â  However, Tharington has standard visitation with his son and provides insurance for him.Â  Although the child may experience some â€œdifficulty, harassment, or embarrassmentâ€ from not having the same last name as his mother, he could also experience â€œdifficulty, harassment or embarrassmentâ€ from not having the last name of his father, with whom he spends considerable time.Â  
Considering the relevant factors, we find it is in Aidanâ€™s best interest that he be given the name Tharington.Â  Accordingly we affirm the family courtâ€™s order changing his name from Aidan John Votor to Aidan John Tharington.2  
3.     Attorneyâ€™s fees
Finally, Votor argues the family court erred in awarding her only $2500.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.Â  
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the sound discretion of the family court.Â  See Bowen v. Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 563, 490 S.E.2d 271, 272 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In determining the reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the court should consider the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
The family court held Votor was entitled to a partial reimbursement of attorneyâ€™s fees, finding at least a portion of the fees incurred were due to the non-cooperation and lack of truthfulness on behalf of Tharington in regards to financial matters.Â  In addition the family court found Tharington was in a much better financial position to satisfy an award of attorneyâ€™s fees and any award of fees would have less impact on Tharington than Votor.Â  The court then thoroughly addressed the Glasscock factors.Â  Importantly, the court found Votor was unsuccessful on almost all monetary issues and the issue of the childâ€™s last name and was only successful in limiting Tharingtonâ€™s request to spend more than standard visitation with his only child.Â  
In reviewing the factors, we find no abuse of discretion in the family court awarding Votor $2500.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the above stated reasons, the order of the family court is 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â 
     

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
2 In determining Aidanâ€™s last name should be changed to Tharington, the family court relied on South Carolina Code section 20-1-70 (1985).Â  Although we find this section not applicable to the present case, we have concluded the change in name is in the childâ€™s best interest and thus affirm the family courtâ€™s decision.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 417, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000) (stating that the appellate court may affirm for any reason appearing in the record).Â Â

title: State v. Cunningham
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Samuel Cunningham, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-541
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 12, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William T. Toal, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Samuel Cunningham appeals his convictions for assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature and armed robbery.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On the second day of Cunninghamâ€™s trial, a juror, Anthony Dolo, sent a note to the judge indicating that â€œ[he] didnâ€™t realize until the end of the day that [he] went to school with Sam [the defendant].Â  [He] wasnâ€™t friends with him.Â  He [the defendant] was in a higher grade . . .â€Â  Following the disclosure of this information, the solicitor requested that Dolo be replaced with an alternate juror.Â  Cunninghamâ€™s counsel objected on the basis that the dismissal of the juror would violate Cunninghamâ€™s rights.Â  Nevertheless, the trial court granted the request and replaced Dolo with an alternate.Â  
During the course of the trial, Cunningham elected not to testify in his own behalf.Â  During closing arguments, the solicitor made reference to money found in Cunninghamâ€™s home subsequent to the robbery at issue.Â  The solicitor stated: Â â€œThe one thing you never got an explanation of is all this money, all this money, all this money thatâ€™s found 16 hours --.â€Â  Cunningham immediately objected to the comment.Â  A conference was held off the record, and the solicitor resumed his argument.Â  
Later in his closing, the solicitor stated â€œwhen they described Samuel Cunningham that night [the night of the robbery], they said he was calm.Â  Thatâ€™s the one thing they said about him, unlike Ronnie Davis [another defendant], he was calm.Â  I think he sat through this entire trial and --.â€Â  Cunningham objected, and the objection was sustained.Â  
During the initial jury charge, the judge instructed the jury that the defendant has a constitutional right to remain silent and has no responsibility to explain anything.Â  He further advised that the defendantâ€™s decision not to testify should not be considered in the deliberations in any way.Â  
Cunningham argued the instruction did not adequately cure any prejudice caused by the solicitorâ€™s previous comments.Â  He claimed the Stateâ€™s first remark about the money that was found implied that the failure to testify and offer an explanation was somehow indicative of guilt.Â  Furthermore, the defense claimed the reference to the robberâ€™s calm demeanor and Cunninghamâ€™s behavior at trial could cause the jury to draw impermissible inferences from Cunninghamâ€™s exercise of the right to remain silent.Â  
In response to Cunninghamâ€™s objection, the trial court re-charged the jury extensively on the subject of the defendantâ€™s constitutional right to remain silent and the legal concept that such silence could not be held against him in any way during jury deliberations.Â  No further objection was made, and no motion for a mistrial was made.Â  The jury returned a verdict of guilty on both counts.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhether to replace a juror with an alternate is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and [an appellate court] will not reverse him on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State v. Hurd, 325 S.C. 384, 480 S.E.2d 94, 97 (Ct. App. 1996) (internal citations omitted).Â  â€œIt is impermissible for the prosecution to comment, directly or indirectly, upon the defendantâ€™s failure to testify.Â  However, improper comments on a defendantâ€™s failure to testify do not automatically require reversal if they are not prejudicial to the defendant.â€Â  Johnson v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 187, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997) (internal citations omitted).Â  An instruction is usually deemed to have cured an error unless, on the facts of the particular case, it is probable that notwithstanding such instruction or withdrawal the accused was prejudiced.Â  State v. Johnson, 334 S.C. 78, 89-90, 512 S.E.2d 795, 801 (1999). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Dismissal of Juror
Cunningham argues on appeal that the trial court committed reversible error and violated Doloâ€™s rights by removing him from the jury.Â  Cunningham also contends that the trial court failed to conduct a probing inquiry to determine if Dolo was unqualified.Â  See State v. Hurd, 325 S.C. 384, 480 S.E.2d at 97 (â€œ[I]t is incumbent upon the trial court to conduct a probing and tactful inquiry to determine whether a sworn juror is unqualified . . . .â€).Â  Although the procedure employed by the trial court may have been irregular, we are not required to address that issue because the record clearly shows that Cunninghamâ€™s objection at trial was based on his rights and not the rights of the juror.Â  
It is well settled that a ground not argued at trial cannot be raised and argued for the first time on appeal.Â  State v. Davis, 354 S.C. 348, 361, 580 S.E.2d 778, 785 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing State v. Dickman, 341 S.C. 293, 524 S.E.2d 268 (2000)); Durham v. Vinson, 360 S.C. 639, 654, 602 S.E.2d 760, 767 (2004) (citing Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 479 S.E.2d 35 (1996)).Â  Consequently, any contention regarding Doloâ€™s rights is not preserved for our review.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Improper Argument
Cunningham next argues that he is entitled to a new trial because the remarks by the State in closing argument were improper and prejudicial, and not cured by the trial courtâ€™s re-charge to the jury.Â  We disagree.Â  
Cunninghamâ€™s first objection to the argument that the jury â€œnever got an explanation of all this money. . . .â€ resulted in a bench conference, but no ruling on the objection on the record.Â  Consequently, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See State v. Rogers, 361 S.C. 178, 183, 603 S.E.2d 910, 912-13 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding that an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court in order to be preserved for appellate review.)Â  
In like fashion, the objection to the Stateâ€™s second â€œdemeanorâ€ argument is not preserved.Â  Cunninghamâ€™s contemporaneous objection to that remark was sustained and, upon his request, the trial court gave a more explicit curative instruction to ameliorate any prejudice the two remarks may have created.Â  However, no objection followed.Â  â€œ[N]o issue is preserved for appellate review if the objecting party accepts the judgeâ€™s ruling and does not contemporaneously make an additional objection to the sufficiency of the curative charge or move for a mistrial.â€Â  State v. McCord, 349 S.C. 477, 486, 562 S.E.2d 689, 694 (Ct. App. 2002) (internal citations omitted).Â  
Based on the foregoing, Cunninghamâ€™s convictions are
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]  
We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation, Respondent,
v.
F.C. â€œTallyâ€ Roberts, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
S. Jackson Kimball, III, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-542
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed October 12, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bruce M. Simpson, of Charlotte, North Carolina and James W. Bradford, Jr., of York, for Appellant.
Robert C. Byrd, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation (GMAC) filed this action to collect on 24 loans personally guaranteed by F.C. â€œTallyâ€ Roberts, Jr.Â  The trial court granted GMACâ€™s motion to add U.S. Bank National Association (U.S. Bank) as a party plaintiff.Â  The court also granted GMACâ€™s motion to strike Robertsâ€™ demand for a jury trial.Â  Roberts appeals.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
The guaranties in this case secured loans totaling greater than $18 million made by Franchise Mortgage Acceptance Company, LLC to either Acme Petroleum and Fuel Company or Acme Properties Limited Partnership (Borrowers).Â  Roberts was the chief executive officer of Borrowers and personally guaranteed the loans.Â  U.S. Bank is the current owner and holder of the loans and guaranties.Â  GMAC is the servicer of the loans and is allegedly authorized to sue on U.S. Bankâ€™s behalf. Â 
After Borrowers defaulted, GMAC filed this collection action.[1]Â  In response, Roberts demanded a jury trial and asserted that GMAC is not the real party in interest and lacks standing to bring the action.Â Â  GMAC moved to join U.S. Bank as a party plaintiff and to strike Robertsâ€™ demand for a jury trial based on waivers contained in the guaranties.Â  
The trial court found the jury trial waivers to be valid and enforceable and granted the motion to join U.S. Bank as a party plaintiff. Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Joinder of U.S. Bank as a Party Plaintiff
Roberts contends the trial court erred in granting the motion to join U.S. Bank as a party plaintiff.Â  We disagree.Â  
The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure permit â€œall personsâ€ to join an action as plaintiffs â€œif they assert any right to relief jointly, severally, or in the alternative in respect of or arising out of the same transaction, occurrence, or series of transactions or occurrences and if any question of law or fact common to all these persons will arise in the action.â€Â  Rule 20(a), SCRCP.Â  In Twelfth RMA Partners v. National Safe Corp., 335 S.C. 635, 638, 518 S.E.2d 44, 45-46 (Ct. App. 1999), a party who was not the holder of a note and guaranty moved on the day of trial to substitute the holder of the note as the proper party.Â  The court allowed the substitution finding no prejudice to the defendant as no new claims were added and the subject of the claim remained the same.Â  Id. at 641, 518 S.E.2d at 47.Â  The court therefore concluded the defendant suffered no prejudice.Â  Id.Â  
Although U.S. Bank was added rather than substituted, we find the analysis in Twelfth RMA Partners sound.Â  U.S. Bankâ€™s claim arises from the same transactions or occurrences as GMACâ€™s claimâ€”the notes and guaranties.Â  Furthermore, the trial court correctly noted that any substantive defenses Roberts has may still be asserted at trial.Â  Roberts has failed to show any prejudice resulting from the joinder.Â  We find the motion for joinder was properly granted.Â  
II.Â  Waiver of Right to Jury Trial
Roberts next argues the trial court erred in granting GMACâ€™s motion to strike his demand for a jury trial, in part because GMAC did not have standing to assert the waivers.Â  We find no error. 
First, we find GMACâ€™s alleged lack of standing immaterial as we find the trial court properly allowed the Bank to be joined as a party.Â  On the merits of the waivers, we likewise find no error.Â  Each guaranty contains the following provision:

21.Â Â Â Â  NO JURY TRIAL.Â  The Guarantors waive all rights to trial by jury in any litigation or other proceeding relating to or arising out of this Guaranty or any of the other Loan Documents.Â  The Guarantors acknowledge that:Â  (i) the provisions of this waiver have been fully disclosed to and discussed by each Guarantor and the Lender, and shall be subject to no exceptions; (ii) this waiver is made knowingly, intentionally and willingly by each Guarantor as part of a bargained-for loan transaction; and (iii) the Lender has not in any way agreed with, represented or intimated to any Guarantor or any of their representatives that the provisions of this waiver shall not be fully enforced in all instances.Â  

Each guaranty also contains a choice of law provision stating that the law of Connecticut applies.Â  
Roberts argues North Carolina law applies under the law of lex loci rei sitae[2] because North Carolina was the principal place of business and the state of Borrowersâ€™ organization.[3]Â  We disagree.Â  A guarantorâ€™s liability is a separate contractual obligation, independent of the obligation on the original note.Â  TranSouth Fin. Corp. v. Cochran, 324 S.C. 290, 295, 478 S.E.2d 63, 65 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Additionally, parties may contractually choose the law that will govern the transaction.Â  See Lybrand v. Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., 321 S.C. 70, 74, 467 S.E.2d 745, 747 (Ct. App. 1996) (enforcing a choice of law provision in an arbitration agreement); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-1-105(1) (2003) (providing that the parties to a transaction may choose by agreement which stateâ€™s law will apply).Â  Furthermore, a number of the loans in this case were secured by property located in South Carolina.Â  We agree with the trial courtâ€™s finding that the guaranties were governed by either South Carolina or Connecticut law.Â  
Under Connecticut law, contractual jury trial waivers are presumptively valid.Â  L & R Realty v. Connecticut Natâ€™l Bank, 715 A.2d 748, 755 (Conn. 1998).Â  To rebut this presumption, the party seeking to avoid the waiver must present evidence that it clearly did not intend to waive the right to a jury trial.Â  Id. at 755-56.Â  Likewise, under South Carolina law, a party may waive the right to a jury trial by contract.Â  Beach Co. v. Twillman, Ltd., 351 S.C. 56, 63-64, 566 S.E.2d 863, 866 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Because the right to trial by jury is a substantial right, the terms of the waiver must be strictly construed.Â  Id.Â  However, the terms of the waiver must be construed using their plain, ordinary and popular meaning.Â  Id.Â  
Roberts argues the waivers are not enforceable because they were not knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently made, in part because he allegedly did not have an opportunity to read the documents at closing.Â  South Carolina law is settled that a person who signs a contract cannot avoid the effect of the document by claiming he did not read it.Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 663, 582 S.E.2d 432, 440 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Under Connecticut law, the burden is on the party seeking to avoid a waiver.Â  L & R Realty, 715 A.2d at 755.Â  
Roberts relies on his affidavit, which states he did not have the opportunity to read the agreements at closing.Â  However, the guaranties provide that Roberts made the waivers knowingly and voluntarily.Â  Furthermore, Roberts is an experienced business person and was represented by a prominent law firm at the time he executed the guaranties.Â  Robertsâ€™ counsel issued an opinion letter to the lender stating he had examined the loan documents and guaranties and had represented Roberts in the transaction.Â  The opinion letter clearly indicated a thorough review of the guaranties, including the waiver provisions.Â  As did the trial court, we find the waiver provisions valid under either South Carolina or Connecticut law.Â  
III.Â  Unpreserved Issues
Roberts raised the following unpreserved issues on appeal:Â  1) application of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-15-102(a); 2) GMACâ€™s waiver by delay; 3) application of waiver of jury trial provision to tort counterclaims; 4) GMACâ€™s improper use of joinder rules; and 5) GMACâ€™s reliance on irrelevant materials not timely submitted to the court.Â  As to the first three issues, these issues are not preserved for appellate review, as they were not ruled upon by the trial court.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  As to the fourth and fifth issues, these issues are not preserved as they were raised for the first time in Robertsâ€™ reply brief.Â  See Continental Ins. Co. v. Shives, 328 S.C. 470, 474 n.2, 492 S.E.2d 808, 811 n.2 (Ct. App. 1997) (An appellant may not use the reply brief to argue issues not argued in the initial brief.).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court properly granted the motion to join U.S. Bank as a party plaintiff.Â  We further find the jury trial waiver provisions are valid and enforceable under either South Carolina or Connecticut law.Â  Accordingly, the order on appeal is 
 AFFIRMED. 
 HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

GMAC originally brought this action in North Carolina and Roberts objected on the ground of lack of personal jurisdiction, as he is a South Carolina resident.Â  GMAC voluntarily dismissed the North Carolina action without prejudice and filed this action in South Carolina.Â

The law of the place where a thing is located.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 911 (6th ed. 1990).
[3]  
Under North Carolina law, a provision for the waiver of the right to a jury trial is unconscionable and unenforceable.Â  N.C. Gen. Stat. Â§ 22B-10 (2005).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

v.
Emerson Rogers, Kathy Rogers, and John Lunn, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Kevin M. Barth, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-543
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 12, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Louis D. Nettles, of Florence, for Appellants.Â  
Robert David McKissick, and S. Porter Stewart, II, both of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Karol and Joy Jamrok appeal the special refereeâ€™s finding that the developer of a subdivision retained the right to grant another resident permission to construct a fence spanning the residentâ€™s property and extending across the developerâ€™s parcel into a pond.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The Jamroks and the Rogerses are neighboring property owners in a cul-de-sac of Village Green III subdivision.Â  Both lots abut a pond.Â  The Jamroks already owned their property when the Rogerses purchased the adjoining lot in 2001.Â  Prior to the Rogersesâ€™ purchase, the previous owner of the lot had built a wrought iron fence extending along the western property line and continuing outward into the pond.Â  The subdivisionâ€™s developer, John Lunn, granted permission for this encroachment pursuant to authority contained in the protective covenants.Â  The Rogerses obtained Lunnâ€™s permission to place architectural fencing along the same route as the wrought iron fence erected by the previous owners.Â  The placement of the fencing prevents the Jamroks from being able to walk around the perimeter of the pond.Â  The Jamroks filed suit against the Rogerses seeking to have the fencing removed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Jamroks seek injunctive relief requiring the Rogerses to remove the fencing.Â  An action for injunctive relief is equitable in nature.Â  Miller v. Borg-Warner Acceptance Corp., 279 S.C. 90, 92, 302 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1983).Â  â€œIn an appeal of an equitable action tried before a master authorized to enter final judgment, this Court must review the entire record and make its own
findings of fact according to its view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  This requirement does not, however, command us to ignore the findings of the trial judge . . . .â€Â  Thomas v. Mitchell, 287 S.C. 35, 37-38, 336 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App. 1985).
LAW/ANALYSIS

The Jamroks argue the special refereeâ€™s decision was in error because the Rogerses and Lunn did not have the right to build the fence so as to exclude them from a common area within the subdivision.Â  We disagree.
The Jamroks contend that the designation of the pond as â€œPondâ€ on the plat of the subdivision makes the pond and the surrounding shoreline common areas from which they cannot be excluded.Â  Assuming arguendo that the pond is a common area, the Jamroks have offered no evidence that they have been excluded from the waters of the pond.Â  Therefore, the only area in issue is the shoreline.Â  
A review of the plat for the subdivision shows the pond is designated as â€œPond,â€ but the area of shoreline immediately adjacent thereto is not marked as common area.Â  See Hamilton v. CCM, Inc., 274 S.C. 152, 158, 263 S.E.2d 378, 381 (1980) (examining a subdivision plat for evidence of a dedicated open space).Â  Neither the Jamroksâ€™ deed nor the Rogersesâ€™ deed references any common areas, and an examination of the protective covenants of the subdivision reveals nothing designating the shoreline as common area.Â  See Newington Plantation Estates Assâ€™n. v. Newington Plantation Estates, 318 S.C. 362, 365, 458 S.E.2d 36, 38 (1995) (reviewing a property ownerâ€™s deed and the relevant restrictive covenants for evidence of easement).Â  Consequently, there is no evidence to support the Jamroksâ€™ argument that the shoreline is a common area.Â  
It is important to note that while the shoreline is not a common area, it is also not the private property of the Jamroks or the Rogerses.Â  It is undisputed that the property lines of both the Jamroks and the Rogerses do not extend all the way to the pond.Â  The shoreline is still under the control of the developer, and its use is governed by the protective covenants of the subdivision.Â  Pursuant to those covenants, the developer retained the right to grant an easement of this type over the shoreline and into the water.[2]Â  Both the Rogerses and their predecessors sought and obtained permission to construct a fence.Â  We find no reason why the provisions of the restrictive covenants are not controlling.Â  
Therefore, we find the shoreline surrounding the pond is not a common area, and the developer was within his rights when he consented to the construction of the fencing.Â  Accordingly the findings of the special referee are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
David Paul Cordle, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-544
Submitted October 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 12, 2005
Â Â  

 AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Aileen P. Clare, of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe all of Columbia;Â  and Â Solicitor Robert M. Ariail of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: David Paul Cordle appeals his conviction of failure to stop for a blue light on the basis of an improper jury charge. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On August 23, 2002, David Cordle, while driving his vehicle, passed Sergeant Rodney Turner and Investigator Wendy Alley on Highway 14 in Greenville County.Â  The posted speed limit on Highway 14 was 45 miles per hour, but Cordle appeared to be traveling at a significantly higher rate of speed.Â  Sergeant Turner and Investigator Alley, of the Greenville-Spartanburg Airport Police, followed and paced Cordle for approximately two miles, eventually determining that the defendant was traveling between 62 and 65 miles per hour.Â  
Sergeant Turner turned on the vehicleâ€™s blue lights and siren, but Cordle refused to stop.Â  Instead, he increased his speed to over 70 miles per hour. Â Cordle was forced to stop about 1 Â½ miles due to heavy traffic at an intersection.Â  When Sergeant Turner approached Cordleâ€™s car, he asked him to either roll down the window completely or get out of the car.Â  Cordle refused. Â Cordleâ€™s window was rolled down just far enough for Sergeant Turner to stick his hand through in an attempt to turn off the engine and retrieve the keys.Â  Once Sergeant Turner placed his hand in the car window, Cordle grabbed his fingers and rolled-up the window on Sergeant Turnerâ€™s arm.Â  They struggled, and Sergeant Turner freed his arm.Â  Investigator Alley opened the car door and removed Cordle from his vehicle. Â Sergeant Turner and Investigator Alley placed him under arrest.Â  
A jury found Cordle guilty on one count of failure to stop for a blue light.Â  He was sentenced to 2 years incarceration, which was suspended to 30 days and 2 years of probation.Â  The circuit court judge allowed Cordle to delay his sentence due to a family medical emergency.Â  The judge warned Cordle that his sentence would be reconsidered if he did not report as ordered.Â  Cordle did not report as required, and he was apprehended in Alabama a few months later.Â  The circuit judge reviewed Cordleâ€™s record, and revoked his probation on prior charges.Â  Prior probation was revoked because Cordle tested positive for methamphetamine, was in arrears regarding his supervision fee, was terminated from the offender treatment program for failure to submit a urine screen and failure to attend class, and was terminated from another treatment program for noncompliance with attendance requirements.Â  Based on Cordleâ€™s behavior, the circuit court judge sentenced him to three years of incarceration.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
Â When reviewing jury charges for error, the appellate court must consider the jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial. Â State v. Todd, 290 S.C 212, 349 S.E.2d 460, 464 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 577 S.E.2d 460, 464 (Ct. App. 2003). â€œIf the charge as a whole is reasonably free from error, isolated portions of the charge which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., Â 334 S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d 570,575 (1999); Cole v. S.C. Elec. & Gas, Inc., 355 S.C. 183, 191, 584 S.E.2d 405,410 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This court must determine whether there is a reasonable likelihood the jury applied a challenged reasonable doubt instruction in a manner that violates the Constitution.Â  State v. Alesky, 343 S.C. 20, 538 S.E.2d 248, 251 (2000).Â  Â 
DISCUSSION
I.                 
Jury Instruction 
Cordle argues that the circuit courtâ€™s jury instruction regarding reasonable doubt unconstitutionally shifted the burden of proof which caused the jury to apply a reduced burden of proof.Â  We disagree. 
Due process does not require that any particular type of words be used to advise the jury of the governmentâ€™s burden of proof, provided the trial court properly instructs the jury that the defendantâ€™s guilt must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Victor v. Nebraska, 511 U.S. 1,5 (1994).Â  Jury instructions are required to correctly communicate the concept of reasonable doubt and nothing more.Â  Id.Â  Proof beyond a reasonable doubt is required in criminal cases by due process; however, trial courts are not required to define reasonable doubt.Â  Victor, 511 U.S. 1,5; see also State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996) (trial judge has the discretion to refuse to define reasonable doubt). 
Jury charges should be examined in their entirety when analyzing whether a defendantâ€™s due process rights have been violated.Â  Todd v. State, 355 S.C 396, 585 S.E.2d 305, 308 (2003).Â  When read as a whole, a jury charge must be substantially correct and cover the law.Â  Adkins, 577 S.E.2d at 463.Â  The substance of the law must be covered in the jury charge.Â  Id.Â  The court instructed the jury:

â€œâ€¦Now in a criminal prosecution of this type as I have said several times, the state, the prosecution fully has the burden of proof. The defense has no burden of proof in these cases.Â  In this state, according to our laws, the prosecution must prove its case to the standard of proof we call â€œbeyond a reasonable doubtâ€ before a finding of guilt may occur.Â  If the state fails to meet this high burden, and it is a high burden, the defendant is entitled to acquittal. 
So to that you say, â€œwell, then what is a reasonable doubt?â€ It is not an imaginary, or a fanciful doubt, or a weak doubt.Â  It is a substantial doubt.Â  It is a doubt which the words imply, a doubt for which you can give or assign a reason based on the testimony and the evidence in the case.Â  A reasonable doubt is not any sort of a doubt you and I know from everyday life experiences. We may have a doubt about any sort of matter no matter how trivial it may be, what tie to wear, what clothes to wear on any occasion. What would I sayâ€”thatâ€™s not a reasonable doubt. 
What a reasonable doubt is is [sic] a doubt which makes an honest sincere, conscientious juror in search of the truth hesitate to act.Â Â  Proof beyond a reasonable doubt is proof that leaves you firmly convinced of the defendantâ€™s guilt.Â  If you have a doubt for which you can give or assign a reason as to the guilt of the defendant then he is entitled to a verdict of not guilty.â€ 

(R. 142-143). 
The language from the jury charge, â€œa doubt which makes an honest, sincere, conscientious juror in search of the truth hesitate to act,â€ and â€œa doubt for which you can give or assign a reason,â€ has been upheld as Constitutional by this appellate court.Â  State v. Needs, 333 S.C. 134, 508 S.E.2d 857, 866-67 (1998).Â Â  The judge repeatedly informed the jury that the state, not the defense, bore the burden of proof.Â  The court properly instructed the jury regarding the reasonable doubt standard by informing the jury that the state had to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  The circuit court did not err in its jury instruction.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, Cordlesâ€™ conviction and sentence are
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concurÂ

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
