THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Michael E. Landry, Sr., Appellant,
v.
Donna E. Lewis, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Judy C. Bridges, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-548
Submitted September 9, 2005 â€“ Filed October 12, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND MODIFIED IN PART 


  
    
      
Frank M. Cisa, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
Donna E. Lewis, Pro Se.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This is an appeal from a post-divorce action in which the trial court denied Husbandâ€™s request to reduce his child support obligation, to require Wife to maintain health insurance for the two minor children, and to award him costs and attorneyâ€™s fees, based on a substantial change in his financial condition.[1]Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and modify in part.[2]Â  
FACTS
Donna E. Lewis (Wife) and Michael E. Landry, Sr. (Husband) were married on July 18, 1994.Â  On June 26, 2001, the trial court granted Wife a divorce on the grounds of â€œhabitual drunkenness caused by the use of illicit drugs.â€Â  In addition, the trial court adopted the partiesâ€™ separation and property settlement agreement, which, among other things, granted custody of the coupleâ€™s two children to Wife and provided Husband would pay $1,300 per month in child support to Wife, based on his imputed income of $80,000.Â  In February 2003, Husband requested a reduction in child support, maintenance of health insurance for the partiesâ€™ children by Wife, and award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to Husband, based upon the loss of his business â€œdue to serious and significant financial difficulties.â€Â  In an amended complaint, Husband also requested â€œspecific rights of visitation with his minor children.â€Â  
The trial courtâ€™s temporary order, issued in December 2003, temporarily denied Husbandâ€™s request for a reduction in child support.Â  However, the trial court ordered Husband to â€œpay the sum of $1,000 per month of his child support obligation with the remaining amount of $300 per month to accrue.â€Â  
At the final hearing, Husband claimed his construction business closed as a result of losing Wifeâ€™s contributions to the operation of the business upon the partiesâ€™ divorce, his extended gall-bladder illness, and his on-going cocaine addition.Â  Husband further presented evidence that since he closed his business in 2002, he has not made more that $910 per week, averaging a gross monthly income of $3,943.Â  Husband also received workersâ€™ compensation from a recent work-related injury, but expected to be back to work in ten to twelve weeks from the date of the hearing.Â  
The trial court found Husbandâ€™s â€œbusiness, closed as a result of the loss of the partnership responsibilities he shared with [Wife] who worked with him during the marriage, and the fact that [Wife] had contributed to the business prior to the partiesâ€™ separation.â€Â  The trial court also attributed blame to Husbandâ€™s drug abuse and gall-bladder disease, which occurred approximately 18 months prior to the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  Nevertheless, the trial court concluded Husband did not show a substantial change of circumstances justifying a reduction in his ongoing child support on a permanent basis because â€œ[c]hanges in financial status as a result of the property division from the divorce are generally in the contemplation of the parties at the time of the divorce and do not qualify as a substantial change.â€Â  The trial court ordered reinstatement of the original child support order on November 1, 2004, less than five months from the hearing date (giving Husband sufficient time to recuperate physically), and required Husband to pay â€œan additional twenty (20%) percent of the on-going child support towards the accumulated child support arrearage.â€Â  It also ordered Husband to provide health insurance for the minor children and pay half of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees, which amounted to $1,930.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the findings of the trial court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the trial court, who saw and heard the witnesses,
was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002). 
LAW/ANALYSIS


Husband claims the trial court erred in failing to reduce his child support obligation because his business failed as a result of the loss of the partnership responsibilities with Wife during the marriage, his gall-bladder disease, and his drug addiction.Â  Further, Husband argues he never made $80,000 annually despite a statement to the contrary in the settlement agreement.Â  We disagree.
Child support awards are within the sound discretion of the trial court and, absent an abuse of discretion, will not be disturbed on appeal.Â 
Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  In determining child support, the trial court must consider both partiesâ€™ incomes, abilities to pay, education, expenses, assets and the facts and circumstances of each case.Â Â  Id.  
The issue of child support is subject to the continuing review of the family court.Â  Id.Â  Child support may be modified upon a proper showing of a change in either the childâ€™s needs or the supporting parentâ€™s financial ability.Â  Calvert v. Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 137, 336 S.E.2d 884, 888 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  It is necessary to show a sufficient change in conditions or circumstances of one or more of the parties or principals.Â  Id.Â  â€œA downward modification of child support based upon a decrease in the noncustodial parentâ€™s income is not warranted absent a strong showing by the party seeking the change that he is no longer in a condition to make the support payments prescribed by an earlier Family Court order.â€Â  Miller v. Miller, 299 S.C. 307, 310-11, 384 S.E.2d 715, 717 (1989).Â  Changes in financial status as a result of the property division from the divorce are generally in the contemplation of the parties at the time of the divorce and do not qualify as a substantial change.Â  Kielar v. Kielar, 311 S.C. 466, 470, 429 S.E.2d 851, 853 (Ct. App. 1993); Kneece v. Kneece, 296 S.C. 28, 35-36, 370 S.E.2d 288, 292-93 (Ct. App. 1988).
Husband suffered from a gall bladder condition in the eighteen months prior to the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  In addition, Husbandâ€™s drug addiction can be traced as far back as 1982. Â In fact, Wife testified Husbandâ€™s drug addiction contributed significantly to the failure of their marriage.Â  Lastly, Husband knew before he signed the settlement agreement that Wife would no longer assist him in the business.Â  Therefore, the changes in his financial status from the illnesses and as a result of the separation were well-within Husbandâ€™s contemplation at the time of the divorce when he signed the settlement agreement stating he made $80,000 annually.Â  Furthermore, Husbandâ€™s financial difficulties are a direct result of many of his own actions.Â  Wife, on the other hand, through no fault of her own, should not be required to lower her and the childrenâ€™s standard of living. 
Husband testified he has made substantial efforts to recover from his drug addiction and, in fact, has been drug free since November 2003.Â  His gall bladder disease is no longer an issue.Â  Furthermore, though he suffered an elbow injury, he expected to return to work soon after the final hearing.Â  We acknowledge Husbandâ€™s efforts to remain drug free and get back to work so that he may provide for his children.Â  Therefore, we modify the trial courtâ€™s final order and forgive Husbandâ€™s arrearages that accrued subsequent to the filing of the pleadings up and until November 1, 2004.Â  We also modify the trial courtâ€™s order, relating to the additional sum Husband is required to pay to reduce any remaining arrearage, from 20% of the ordered amount ($1,300 per month) to $100 per month.Â  However, Husband failed to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that he suffered a sufficient change in his financial condition to warrant a downward modification of child support.Â  Therefore, as of November 1, 2004, Husband is ordered to pay the $1,300 per month in child support as awarded to Wife in the original action plus $100 per month toward the arrearage.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s order is hereby 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND MODIFIED IN PART.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
HUFF, WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â Â Â Â

[2] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â

title: Jacobs v. Jackson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Margaret Jacobs, Appellant,
v.
Roxie J. Jackson, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marion County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-549
Submitted October 10, 2005 â€“ Filed October 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ms. Margaret Jacobs, of Dillon, for Appellant
Louis David Nettles, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action arising from an automobile accident, Margaret Jacobs appeals the juryâ€™s verdict in favor of Roxie J. Jackson.Â  We affirm.Â  1
FACTS
On December 6, 1999, Jacobs and Jackson were involved in an automobile accident at an intersection controlled by a traffic light.Â  Both parties contended they had the right of way through the intersection.Â  According to the investigating officer, Brad Sawyer, Jacobs told him that she had stopped at the red light and then proceeded through the intersection when the light turned green.Â  Sawyer testified that Jackson stated the light had turned yellow, but â€œshe thought she had it and could beat it.â€Â  In his accident report, Sawyer noted that Jackson failed to yield the right of way at the traffic light and struck Jacobsâ€™ vehicle.Â  During his testimony, Sawyer opined that Jackson was at fault.Â  The court ruled that Sawyer was not allowed to give his opinion and instructed the jury that the determination of who was at fault was left to them.Â  
During the trial, Jackson testified that the light was green when she entered the intersection.Â  At the time of the trial, Jackson was 82 years old.Â  
The jury found in favor of Jackson.Â  They answered â€œnoâ€ to the following question: â€œDo you find that the defendant was negligent and that such negligence proximately caused the plaintiffâ€™s injuries.â€Â  The trial court denied Jacobsâ€™ post-trial motions.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
In her statement of the issues on appeal, Jacobs sets forth 3 issues:

  
    
      
        1.  
         Whether defendant-respondent is immune from all liability due to her age based on the grounds of negligence that led to an auto accident.
      
      
        2. 
         Whether Judge erred in not allowing Officer for Appellant to convey all facts during trial that disallowed due process.
      
      
        3. 
         Whether ruling in case against appellant was based on lack of evidence or did the arms of justice elude appellant based on fact respondent was elderly, the jurors knew respondent and exhibited sympathy based on her location and age.
      
    
  

However, Jacobsâ€™ entire argument section is only one page long and fails to cite to any relevant authority.Â  Accordingly, her argument may be deemed conclusory and abandoned. See Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œSouth Carolina law clearly states that short, conclusory statements made without supporting authority are deemed abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for review.â€); State v. Colf, 332 S.C. 313, 504 S.E.2d 360 (Ct. App. 1998) (deeming abandoned a conclusory, two-paragraph argument that cited no authority other than an evidentiary rule).Â  The fact that Jacobs is proceeding pro se does not relieve her of the responsibility of complying with all procedural and substantive requirements.Â  See State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, 589 S.E.2d 6, 9 n.5 (2003) (â€œA pro se litigant who knowingly elects to represent himself assumes full responsibility for complying with substantive and procedural requirements of the law.â€).
Although we recommend affirming with a Rule 220, SCACR, opinion we will briefly address Jacobsâ€™ issues.Â  
Jacobs argues the trial court erred in not allowing the investigating officer to convey all of the facts.Â  We disagree.Â  
Officer Sawyer testified that because of Jacksonâ€™s age, he did not issue a citation to her, even though she was at fault.Â  Jacksonâ€™s attorney objected to Sawyer testifying as to fault.Â  The trial court instructed the jury that the determination of who was at fault was for them to make.Â  Sawyer attempted to argue against this ruling, but the court affirmed that it would not permit him to give his opinion as to who caused the accident.Â  Jacobs did not make any argument against this ruling nor did she proffer any testimony further on the issue.Â  She never attempted to have Sawyer designated an expert witness.Â  
A trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit or exclude evidence is within his discretion and will not be disturbed unless an abuse of discretion occurs. Â Â Pike v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 234, 540 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2000).Â  Rule 701, SCRE provides:Â  â€œIf the witness is not testifying as an expert, the witnessâ€™s testimony in the form of opinions or inferences is limited to those opinions or inferences which (a) are rationally based on the perception of the witness, (b) are helpful to a clear understanding of the witnessâ€™s testimony or the determination of a fact in issue, and (c) do not require special knowledge, skill, experience or training.â€Â  â€œA long line of South Carolina decisions has excluded the opinions of investigating police officers in automobile accident cases.â€Â  Gulledge v. McLaughlin, 328 S.C. 504, 508, 492 S.E.2d 816, 818Â  (Ct. App. 1997); see State v. Kelly, 285 S.C. 373, 374, 329 S.E.2d 442, 443 (1985) (â€œA police officer may not give his opinions as to the cause of an accident.Â  He may only testify regarding his direct observations unless he is qualified as an expert.â€).Â Â  
Sawyer acknowledged that he did not see the accident occur, nor did he speak to any witnesses to the accident, or view any pictures or videotape of the accident.Â  His conclusion was based solely on the partiesâ€™ statements to him.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s exclusion of his opinion.Â  
Jacobs also contends that Jackson was at fault for the accident.Â  We find no reversible error.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried by a jury, the jurisdiction of this Court extends merely to the correction of errors of law, and a factual finding of the jury will not be disturbed unless a review of the record discloses that there is no evidence which reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.â€Â Â  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).

[I]t is not unusual for a case to have contradictory evidence and inconsistent testimony from a witness.Â  In a law case tried before a jury, it is the jury that must decide what part of the witnessâ€™s testimony it wants to believe and what part it wants to disbelieve.Â  Under such circumstances, it is not the function of this Court to weigh the evidence and determine the credibility of the witnesses.Â  

Small v. Pioneer Machinery, Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 465, 494 S.E.2d 835, 843-44 (Ct. App.1997).
In the present case, both parties claimed to have the right-of-way.Â  Although there is contrary evidence, Jacksonâ€™s testimony that she had the green light supports the juryâ€™s verdict in her favor.Â  Accordingly, we must affirm the verdict.Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ann M. Clayton, Respondent,
v.
Malcolm T. Clayton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Bamberg County
Agnes Dale Gable , Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-550
Heard September 14, 2005 â€“ Filed October 14, 2005

REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., of Columbia and Miles Loadholt, of Barnwell, for Appellant.
William D. Rhoad, IV, of Bamberg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Malcolm Clayton (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s distribution of property following his divorce, arguing the court erred in finding certain inherited property was transmuted into marital property.Â  Husband also argues error in the courtâ€™s valuation of the partiesâ€™ deferred compensation accounts.Â  We reverse in part and remand.
FACTS
Ann Clayton (Wife) and Husband were married on February 17, 1955.Â  Shortly after their marriage, Husbandâ€™s mother gifted him 25 acres of property for consideration of $1.Â  The parties resided in the marital home constructed on this property for the entire duration of their marriage â€“ 44 years.Â  In 1963, Husbandâ€™s father died, leaving his wife a life estate in 72 acres adjacent to Husbandâ€™s 25 acres with a remainder interest to Husband.Â  Upon Husbandâ€™s motherâ€™s death in 1967, Husband received full title to the 72 acres. Â 
On June 17, 2002, the trial court granted Wife a divorce based on one yearâ€™s separation and reserved jurisdiction to determine equitable division.Â  Upon completion of court-ordered appraisals of the real property and farm equipment, the family court issued a final order as to the division of marital property, providing â€œthat all marital assets should be divided on a 50/50 basis,â€ excepting â€œsome slight differences in the values of the direct retirement accounts of the parties.â€Â  The trial court specifically found â€œTract #1,â€ a 97-acre parcel of land with a residence and several farm buildings valued at $147,000, â€œto be marital property and is to be included in the marital estate.â€Â  The 97-acre parcel designated â€œTract #1â€ in the family court order consisted of the 25-acre tract acquired in 1955 and the 72-acre tract acquired by inheritance in 1967.Â  
Both parties filed motions for reconsideration.Â  The family court issued an order clarifying the original distribution of both partiesâ€™ deferred compensation accounts, valuing the Husbandâ€™s accounts at $298,217, as listed in his financial declaration, and Wifeâ€™s account at $51,600.Â  In all other regards, the order reiterated the family courtâ€™s prior order.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We remain mindful that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Transmutation
Husband claims the trial court erred in finding the 72-acre parcel he inherited from his father was transmuted into marital property.Â  We agree.
Marital property is generally defined as all real and personal property acquired by the parties during the marriage that is owned on the date of filing or commencement of the marital litigation, regardless of how legal title is held.Â Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  Exempted from the above definition, however, is â€œproperty acquired by either party by inheritance, devise, bequest, or gift from a party other than the spouse.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(1) (Supp. 2004).Â  Upon dissolution of the marriage, marital property should be divided and distributed in a manner that fairly reflects each spouseâ€™s contribution to its acquisition.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 293, 372 S.E.2d 107, 109 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The family court, however, has no jurisdiction to divide nonmarital property.Â  Skipper v. Skipper, 290 S.C. 412, 413. 351 S.E.2d 153, 154 (1986).Â  
In certain circumstances, nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital property if:Â  (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable;Â  (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property.Â Â  Johnson, 296 S.C. at 295, 372 S.E.2d at 110.Â  Whether or not nonmarital property has been transmuted is a matter of intent to be gleaned from the facts of each case.Â  Id.Â Â  
It is well settled that â€œthe spouse claiming an equitable interest in property upon dissolution of the marriage has the burden of proving the property is part of the marital estate.â€Â  Id. at 294, 372 S.E.2d at 110Â  (citing Roberts v. Roberts, 296 S.C. 93, 370 S.E.2d 881 (Ct. App. 1988)).Â  Thus, a spouse
claiming transmutation must produce objective evidence showing that, during the marriage, the parties themselves regarded the property as the common property of the marriage.Â  Id. at 295, 372 S.E.2d at 110-111.Â  
In the present case, Wifeâ€™s sole basis for proving transmutation was some nonspecific testimony by the parties that Husband sporadically used some marital income in support of the farming business, which he operated on the land in question, as well as proceeds from the business in support of the marriage.Â  â€œThe mere use of separate property to support the marriage, without some additional evidence of intent to treat it as property of the marriage, is not sufficient to establish transmutation.â€Â  Pool v. Pool, 321 S.C. 84, 88, 467 S.E.2d 753, 756 (Ct. App. 1996), affâ€™d as modified, 329 S.C. 324, 494 S.E.2d 820 (1998); see also Murray v. Murray, 312 S.C. 154, 157, 439 S.E.2d 312, 315 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Wife presented no additional evidence that the couple regarded the property as the common property of the marriage.Â  Accordingly, the family court erred in finding the inherited 72-acre parcel was transmuted into marital property.
II. Valuation of deferred compensation accounts
Husband claims the trial court erred in computing and allocating the total value of the deferred compensation accounts of the parties.Â  We agree and remand the case for a reevaluation of this issue.Â  
In order to equitably divide the partiesâ€™ deferred compensation accounts, the family court valued the accounts of each spouse, added both together, and granted each spouse 50% of the total.Â  In valuing Husbandâ€™s accounts, the family court relied on the value presented by Husband in his financial declaration, $298,217.Â  Our concern, however, lies with the valuation of Wifeâ€™s accounts.Â  Documents provided in the record on appeal vaguely reflect three differing values attributed to Wifeâ€™s accounts - $75,609.05, $126,858.08, and $70, 047.77.Â  Addressing this issue, the family courtâ€™s final order simply states, â€œ[Wife] also had a deferred compensation account that had a present value of $51,600.00 at the time of filing.â€Â  We find, as Wifeâ€™s counsel conceded in oral argument, nothing whatsoever in the record supporting this valuation.Â  Because the family courtâ€™s order and record on appeal provide no guidance as to how this figure was determined, we remand this issue for reconsideration.
For the reasons stated above, the family courtâ€™s decision is hereby
 REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.
HUFF, WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

title: State Capital Insurance Company v. Forrest
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
State Capital Insurance Company, Appellant/Respondent,
v.
Jill Johnson Forrest, Scott Gordon Forrest, Karen B. Smith, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Joseph Drew Smith, a Minor, Deceased,
Respondents,
and Randall W. Smith, Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-552
Heard September 14, 2005 â€“ Filed October 17, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John H. Tiller, of Charleston, for Appellant-Respondent.
Edwin R. Jeter, Daryl L. Williams, of Columbia, Robert L. Buchanan, of Aiken, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  State Capital Insurance Company (â€œState Capitalâ€) appeals a portion of a declaratory judgment finding two separate â€œoccurrencesâ€ under the terms of a homeownerâ€™s insurance policy.Â  Randall W. Smith also appeals a portion of the order.Â  We affirm.
FACTS / PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On July 18, 1997, Jill and Scott Forrest set out by boat with two other couples from their home on Lake Murray for a restaurant and bar on the lakeâ€™s opposite shore.Â  On board were at least two cases of beer.Â  The entire party consumed alcohol throughout the trip and subsequent dinner with the exception of Scott Forrest, who stopped drinking at the restaurant in anticipation of operating the boat on the trip home.Â  The party did not decide to head for home until the early morning hours of July 19.Â  Before leaving the bar and restaurant, the group became aware that the stern light, required for nighttime navigation, was inoperable, but decided to make the return trip anyway.Â  Despite the fact that Scott was the most sober of the group, Jill Forrest captained the boat on the way home.
That same evening, Randall Smith and his eleven-year-old son, Drew, were night fishing on the lake on a small fishing boat.Â  Shortly after leaving the restaurant, the Forrestsâ€™ boat collided with Mr. Smithâ€™s boat, killing his young son and sinking the smaller vessel.Â  Several of the Forrestsâ€™ passengers were thrown from their boat.Â  Following the collision, Mr. Forrest took control of their boat and began to pick up his passengers.Â  Deception on the part of the Forrests and their passengers regarding the circumstances of the accident began almost immediately. 
As Mr. Smith floated in the lake, cradling the lifeless body of his son, Mrs. Forrest told her husband that he should tell the authorities he was operating the boat so that assets in her name would not be subject to liability.Â  The Forrests persuaded the other passengers to go along with this version of the events, and several members of the group promptly began sinking beer cans in the lake to conceal evidence of their earlier drinking.Â  Due to their deception, it was Mr. Forrest, and not Mrs. Forrest, who was administered a field sobriety test upon the authoritiesâ€™ arrival. Most significant to the present appeal, Mr. Forrest claimed during the investigation that Mr. Smith was operating his boat at night without proper lighting, effectively accusing him of unlawful conduct.Â  So clear was the inference of Mr. Smithâ€™s fault, he was given Miranda warnings prior to questioning by the investigating officers. The Forrests also told investigators that their boat had a functioning stern light at the time of the collision, which was another intentional falsehood.
The Forrestsâ€™ ruse was maintained for a few weeks, as much of the investigation focused on Mr. Smith and whether he maintained proper lighting on his fishing boat.Â  Due to some inconsistencies in the passengersâ€™ stories, however, the focus of the investigation began to shift to the Forrests.Â  Weeks after the collision, two of the Forrestsâ€™ passengers confessed to law enforcement regarding the operator of the watercraft at the time of the accident, the status of its stern light, and the concealment of evidence.[1] Â 
Mr. Smith brought an action against the Forrests, asserting claims based on their negligence in operating the boat as well as their deceitful actions following the accident.Â  Karen Smith, Drewâ€™s mother, brought a wrongful death action based on her capacity as personal representative of Drewâ€™s estate.Â  Based on a homeownerâ€™s insurance policy in effect at the time of the accident, State Capital agreed to defend the Forrests under a reservation of rights in these cases.Â  However, State Capital promptly filed a declaratory judgment action seeking to deny coverage to the Forrests based on two issues relating to ownership of the boat and the residence of Jill Forrestâ€™s mother, record owner of the boat they were using on the night of the accident.Â  Due to their interest in the outcome of the declaratory judgment action, the Smiths were also named as party defendants.
On February 19, 2003, a non-jury trial was held on State Capitalâ€™s action.Â  The primary focus of the trial was the factual determinations relating to the ownership of the boat and the residence of Mrs. Forrestâ€™s mother.Â  Near the close of trial, however, the attorney for the Smiths, heretofore silent as to the initial two issues, addressed the court.Â  At this time, he raised the issue of the accident and the Forrestsâ€™ behavior that followed as possibly giving rise to two separate â€œoccurrencesâ€ under the terms of the insurance policy.Â  The insurance policy in question limits recovery to $300,000 per â€œoccurrence.â€Â  It was the Smithsâ€™ position that, under the present facts, State Capital faced potential liability of $600,000.
The circuit court requested and received memoranda from State Capital and Mr. Smith on this issue. On May 29, 2003, the circuit issued its final order.Â  The court rejected State Capitalâ€™s position on the issues relating to ownership of the boat and the residency of Mrs. Forrestâ€™s mother.Â  The order further held that the policy provided insurance for both the first â€œoccurrenceâ€ of the boating accident and the second â€œoccurrenceâ€ of the alleged defamation, for which State capital was also required to defend and indemnify up to a separate policy limit.Â  State Capital promptly moved for reconsideration of the portion of the order finding that there was a second occurrence under the policy.Â  Mr. Smith also moved to conform his pleadings to the evidence in order to better articulate his defamation claim and how it relates to the Forrestsâ€™ specific insurance policy.
Before the post-trial motions were argued, both Mrs. Smithâ€™s wrongful death action and Mr. Smithâ€™s property damage and emotional distress claims were settled.Â  Only Mr. Smithâ€™s defamation claim, arising from the conspiracy which placed suspicion for causing the accident on him, remained.Â  Following a hearing on the post-trial motions presently on appeal, the conspiracy trial went forward.Â  Before its conclusion, a settlement was reached, valuing Mr. Smithâ€™s defamation claim at $250,000 to be deposited with the Lexington County Clerk of Court and paid out pursuant to further direction by the court following resolution of the post-trial motions and the present appeal.
The circuit court denied State Capitalâ€™s motion for reconsideration, upholding the portion of its order finding two â€œoccurrencesâ€ under the policy.Â  The court likewise denied Mr. Smithâ€™s motion to amend his pleadings, concluding that the motion was rendered moot by the caseâ€™s favorable conclusion.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A declaratory judgment action to determine coverage under an insurance contract is an action at law.Â  Travelers Indem. Co. v. Auto World of Orangeburg, Inc., 334 S.C. 137, 140, 511 S.E.2d 692, 694 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, the appellate court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless there is no reasonable evidence supporting them.Â  Townes Assocs. Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  The scope of our review of this case is therefore limited to the correction of errors of law.Â  Id.
DISCUSSION
State Capital argues the trial court erred in finding a second occurrence under the policy and extending coverage under a separate policy limit to the defamation claim.Â  We disagree.
The general guidelines for interpreting insurance policies were recently outlined by this court as follows:

Insurance policies are subject to general rules of contract construction.Â  This Court must enforce, not write, contracts of insurance and we must give policy language its plain, ordinary, and popular meaning.Â  All of the policy provisions should be considered, and one may not, by pointing out a single sentence or clause, create an ambiguity.Â  The meaning of a particular word or phrase is not determined by considering the word or phrase by itself, but by reading the policy as a whole and considering the context and subject matter of the insurance contract.
An insurerâ€™s obligation under a policy of insurance is defined by the terms of the policy itself, and cannot be enlarged by judicial construction.Â  Ambiguous or conflicting terms in an insurance policy must be construed liberally in favor of the insured and strictly against the insurer.Â  However, if the intention of the parties is clear, courts have no authority to torture the meaning of policy language to extend or defeat coverage that was never intended by the parties.
The rule of strict construction does not authorize a perversion of language or the exercise of inventive powers for the purpose of creating an ambiguity where none exists.Â  When a contract is unambiguous, clear, and explicit, it must be construed according to the terms the parties have used.Â  The judicial function of a court of law is to enforce an insurance contract as made by the parties, and not to rewrite or to distort, under the guise of judicial construction, contracts, the terms of which are plain and unambiguous.

Stewart v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 341 S.C. 143, 150-151, 533 S.E.2d 597, 601 (Ct. App. 2000) (internal citations omitted).
The homeownerâ€™s policy at issue in the present case expressly provides coverage for â€œbodily injuryâ€ and â€œproperty damageâ€ caused by an â€œoccurrence.â€ The policyâ€™s definitions clause defines â€œoccurrenceâ€ as â€œan accident, including continuous or repeated exposure to substantially the same general harmful conditions, which results, during the policy period, in:Â  a. â€˜bodily injury;â€™ or b. â€˜property damage.â€™â€Â  The policy includes a â€œspecial coverage extension,â€ which expands the definition of â€œbodily injuryâ€ to include â€œpersonal injury.â€Â  â€œPersonal Injuryâ€ is defined as â€œinjury arising out of one or more of the following offenses:Â  2. libel, slander or defamation of character.â€
Initially, we must settle an apparent ambiguity in the policy.Â  Although the policy defines â€œoccurrenceâ€ as â€œan accident,â€ the policyâ€™s definition of covered personal injuries specifically includes defamation, an intentional tort.Â  â€œThus, the policy purports to provide coverage for certain intentional torts under [its] definition of covered personal injuries, yet it attempts to deny coverage for injuries expected or intended under the definition of an occurrence.â€Â  South Carolina State Budget & Control Bd. v. Prince, 304 S.C. 241, 248, 403 S.E.2d 643, 647 (1991).Â  When a policy is, such as this one, â€œsusceptible to more than one reasonable interpretation, one of which would provide coverage, [an appellate court] must hold as a matter of law in favor of coverage.â€Â  Gaskins v. Blue Cross-Blue Shield of South Carolina, 271 S.C. 101, 108, 245 S.E.2d 598, 602 (1978).Â  Thus, when faced with a similar policy and the issue of whether damages caused by defamation were covered, our supreme court found that the defamation was an â€œoccurrenceâ€ under the policy, stating â€œ[i]t would be unreasonable to interpret this policy to exclude coverage for defamation when the policy specifically includes defamation as a covered personal injury.â€Â  Prince, 304 S.C. at 248, 403 S.E.2d at 647. 
We similarly conclude that the defamation of Mr. Smith constitutes a second â€œoccurrenceâ€ under the policy.Â  â€œThe majority of courts have adopted the general view that to determine whether there is a single or multiple occurrence or accident within the meaning of the policy limits clause of a liability policy one must look to the cause or causes of the accident or occurrence.â€Â  Michael P. Sullivan, Annotation, What Constitutes Single Accident or Occurrence Within Liability Policy Limiting Insurerâ€™s Liability To A Specified Amount Per Accident Or Occurrence, 64 A.L.R. 4th 668 (2005).Â  Applying this analysis to a â€œper personâ€ liability cap, this court held that injuries to a second person are not recoverable under a separate policy limit when they are â€œconsequential damages,â€ flowing from the same cause as the injuries to the initially injured party.Â  See Stewart, 341 S.C. at 159,Â  533 S.E.2d at 605.Â  Mr. Smithâ€™s defamation claim, however, is in no way â€œconsequentialâ€ to the boating accident.Â  
The actions of the insureds giving rise to the defamation claim did not occur during the accident.Â  They began during the investigation following the collision and continued for several subsequent weeks.Â  Although the conspiracy placing blame for the accident on Mr. Smith certainly relates to the boating accident, the cause of the defamatory injuries is solely the intentional deceptive behavior of the Forrests and their guests in the weeks following the accident.Â  This is a wholly different cause than that of the accident itself, which was caused by the negligent behavior of Mrs. Forrest before and during the collision.Â  Because the behavior giving rise to Mr. Smithâ€™s defamatory injuries began considerably after the accident and continued for weeks following the death of his son, it would be unreasonable to construe the Forrestsâ€™ deplorable behavior as a mere natural â€œconsequenceâ€ of the collision.
In support of their contention, State Capitalâ€™s brief focuses on case law interpreting the phrase â€œarising out ofâ€ and its proper construction in an insurance contract to conclude there was only one â€œoccurrence.â€Â  These cases, however, deal solely with insurance policy clauses outlining what kind of damages are and are not covered by the policies, i.e. clauses of inclusion (stating what kind of damages are covered by the policy) and clauses of exclusion (outlining which damages are not covered).Â  See, e.g., Howard v. State Farm Mutual Auto. Ins. Co., 316 S.C. 445, 450, 450 S.E.2d 582, 585 (1994) (holding an appellate court must construe the phrase â€œarising out ofâ€ broadly in a clause of inclusion); McPherson v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co., 310 S.C. 316, 319-320, 426 S.E.2d 770, 771 (1993) (holding an appellate court must construe the phrase â€œarising out ofâ€ narrowly in a clause of exclusion).Â  State Capital would have us ask, â€œdid the defamation â€˜arise out ofâ€™ the boat collision?â€Â  Applying a broad interpretation of the phrase â€œarising out of,â€ the answer is clearly â€œyes.â€Â  Thus, argues State Capital, there is only one â€œoccurrence.â€Â  However, at issue in the present case is not what kind of damages are included or excluded under the policyâ€™s coverage.Â  It is undisputed that damages â€œarising out ofâ€ defamation are covered;[2] thus, the phrase, which appears only in the context of defining what constitutes a â€œpersonal injury,â€ has little relevance to the matter presently before us.Â  State Capital asks us to apply the broad interpretation of the phrase â€œarising out ofâ€ to the definition of â€œoccurrence,â€ even though the phrase â€œarising out ofâ€ appears nowhere in that definition.Â  As stated above, the proper test to determine if there was more than one â€œoccurrenceâ€ is not whether some damages â€œarise out ofâ€ others, but whether the damages can be attributed to the same cause.Â  Because we find, under the unique factual circumstances of the present case, the defamatory injuries suffered by Mr. Smith had a separate cause than those resulting from the accident itself, we conclude there were two separate â€œoccurrencesâ€ under the policy.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s decision is therefore
AFFIRMED.[3]
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â  

[1] On August 11, 1999, Mrs. Forrest pled guilty to 1) reckless homicide by operation of a boat, 2) obstruction of justice, 3) criminal conspiracy, 4) violation of duties of a vessel operator involved in a collision, and 5) violation of U.S. Coast Guard Navigational Rules.Â  Mr. Forrest pled guilty toÂ  1) obstruction of justice and 2) criminal conspiracy. 
[2] As previously stated, State Capital has acknowledged the damages resulting from the defamation in this case and the fact that they are covered under the policy, disputing only the issue of whether the damages constitute a second â€œoccurrence.â€
[3]Â  Because this issue is decided in Mr. Smithâ€™s favor, we also affirm the circuit courtâ€™s denial of Mr. Smithâ€™s request to amend his pleadings in order to better argue the issue.
