PREHEARING REPORT


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Carolyn Sargent, Appellant,
In Re:  Willie Sargent, Employee,
        v.
International Paper Co.,Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-553
Submitted October 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 17, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas J. Rubillo, of Georgetown, for Appellant.
Kirsten Leslie Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, Roy Allen Howell, III, of Â Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, Carolyn Sargent appeals the trial courtâ€™s order affirming the order of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Commission) denying benefits to Carolyn for the death of her husband, Willie Sargent.Â  We affirm.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This case involves the unfortunate and untimely death of a conscientious, long-time employee of International Paper.Â  Carolyn Sargent filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim against International Paper asserting her husband sustained an injury by accident to his lungs resulting in his death.Â  At the hearing before the Single Commissioner, Carolyn took the position that Willieâ€™s death resulted from his accidental exposure to chlorine dioxide (ClO2).Â  Specifically, Carolyn maintained Willie was working as a mechanic when he went to repair a pump that contained ClO2 and, as he was working on the machine, he â€œcaught a pretty good dose of it.â€Â  Her position was that Willie died from pneumonia that was induced, at least in part, by exposure to the chemical.Â  
The record shows Willie Sargent was employed at International Paper as a Service Operator I.Â  His duties were testing and trouble shooting, which involved checking on jobs to see if there were any problems.Â  Luther Davis testified that he worked with Willie and held the same job at International Paper.Â  According to Davis, he worked with Willie on the Friday before Willie was admitted to the hospital, which would have been August 18, 2000.Â  The first time he saw Willie that day was around 6:30 a.m. in the lab, and Willie was â€œdoing pretty goodâ€ at that time.Â  The two men parted company, and Davis thereafter saw Willie in the lab again.Â  Davis described Willieâ€™s physical condition at that time as â€œpretty good.â€Â  Willie was called to check on a pump at the â€œKMYR digester,â€ and Davis was called to assist him.Â  After the two opened a valve, Willie was again called away, this time to go to a job on the â€œpine decker.â€Â  Thereafter when Davis saw Willie, Willie was â€œcoughing pretty forcefully.â€Â  Davis had worked on the C line that day where there was â€œ a little, small ClO2 leak.â€Â  When he last saw Willie before he observed him coughing, Willie was â€œheaded in the direction of the C lineâ€ of the plant.Â  However, the place that Willie was ultimately going to was not the C line, but was the pine decker.Â  Davis testified that if there were any problems on the jobs they checked, they normally would not fix anything, but would just report the problem.Â  Davis specifically testified Willie would not have been performing any repairs on a leak on the C line when he was called away.Â  Although he was not sure, Davis thought he told Willie about the leak he had discovered on the C line that morning.Â  However, he stated that people would still walk through the area knowing of a leak because the C line is outside, in the open air.Â  
Thomas Carucci, International Paperâ€™s safety manager, testified regarding the plantâ€™s protocol following an employeeâ€™s exposure to ClO2.Â  Carucci stated that after an employee reports an exposure, a green slip is used to document the occurrence and an investigation is immediately triggered.Â  If an exposure were reported, maintenance would be notified there was a leak, an analysis would be performed, and â€œimmediately things would be shut down and it would be taped off or roped off so no one could go into the area.â€Â  Carucci stated International Paper had no record of Willie reporting any problems due to exposure prior to his hospitalization and death.Â  Carucci further testified, if Willie had reported an exposure when he went to first aid on August 22, a green slip would have been filled out immediately and the area would have been tested and roped off.Â  Because it was not reported, no green form was filled out for Willie.Â  Carruci also testified that the C line was in a big, open area and was completely outside.Â  
Jacob Smith, the manufacturing manager at International Paper, testified regarding Willieâ€™s position and his employment with the company.Â  Willie worked for a foreman who worked for Smith.Â  Willieâ€™s responsibility was to walk a route throughout the manufacturing process to observe any kind of malfunction with the equipment in that area.Â  Willie would report any mechanical problems.Â  Smith testified Willie never performed any major repairs and if there were a mechanical malfunction that required repair work, maintenance would perform the work, as it was not a part of Willieâ€™s job.Â  Smith had known Willie for twenty-nine years and stated Willie smoked â€œquite a bitâ€ and had complained about breathing problems.Â  Willie was a â€œvery conscientiousâ€ employee who was well trained and aware of the proper procedure to follow in the case of exposure to ClO2.Â  Prior to his death, Willie did not report he had been acutely exposed to ClO2.Â  Neither was there any record Willie reported any sort of mechanical problems between August 17 and Willieâ€™s death on August 30.Â  According to Smith, if Willie had â€œgotten a whiff of any significant amountâ€ of ClO2,â€ he would have reported it.Â  
Willie did not work on Saturday, August 19 or Sunday, August 20, but did work a 3:00 to 11:00 shift on Monday, August 21.Â  On August 22, 2000, Willie went to see one of the companyâ€™s occupational health nurses, Mary Ann Sutton.Â  At that time, Willie complained of not feeling well for two days and experiencing shortness of breath upon exertion.Â  He further complained of nausea and having a productive cough.Â  He had a temperature of 100 degrees.Â  Sutton found Willieâ€™s chest sounded clear, she heard no wheezes, and there was no complaint of chest pain.Â  Sutton noted it appeared Willie had a flu-like illness.Â  She encouraged Willie to go home, but he indicated he had one and a half hours left on his shift that he wanted to finish.Â  Willie agreed he would call his doctor the next morning or visit the emergency room if his symptoms continued to increase.Â  
Sutton testified the company had policies and procedures in place whenever someone reported any inhalation of gas.Â  She stated an incident report and respiratory forms would be filled out, and management and the safety department would be notified.Â  Had Willie reported an exposure to ClO2 at that time, she would have filled out another document as well as her regular nurseâ€™s notes.Â  This document is an occupational health nurse note that is on a green form.Â  Sutton testified that with an acute exposure to ClO2, the person would be aware of the exposure right away because it has a bad smell and is irritating.Â  The person would complain of a lot of burning in the throat.Â  She stated ClO2 is a strong respiratory irritant and that if a person could not get away from the area and inhaled a large amount, it would result in wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, vomiting, and several hours later the person may develop pulmonary edema.Â  It is clear from Suttonâ€™s notes and her testimony that Willie did not report any ClO2 exposure to her when he saw her on August 22.Â  
Carolyn Sargent testified before the Commission that she first became aware her husband was having problems with his health on Sunday, when â€œ[h]e was coughing and he was aching all over.â€Â  He had been off that day and the day before, but worked the day prior to that, and when he came home from work that day, he was not having any difficulty.Â  Willie went to see his doctor on Wednesday morning.Â  While there, the doctor called an ambulance to transport Willie to the hospital.Â  Willie died the following Wednesday morning.Â  Carolyn acknowledged she stated in her deposition that the first time Willie complained to her was on Tuesday night, August 22, but clarified that was the first time Willie complained about â€œinhaling the ClO2 gas.â€Â  Carolyn agreed Willie had a history of smoking, at least for the twenty-six years she was married to him.Â  
The record further shows Willie was admitted to Georgetown Memorial Hospital on August 23, 2000.Â  Nursing notes reflect Willie stated â€œClO2 â€“ bleaching agent â€“ was released into air last [Thursday]â€ and Willie â€œwent [through] area 3 times in 10 [minutes].â€Â  One of the consulting physicians, Dr. Phillips, documented the following:Â  â€œThe patient states approximately a week or so ago he was exposed to a chemical spill at the plant.Â  He describes this being a chloride-based bleach spill.â€Â  Another consulting physician, Dr. Felzien, also noted, â€œThe patient was initially involved in a chemical spill felt to be some type of chloride-based chemical approximately one week prior to admission.â€Â  On evaluation, it was determined Willie had pneumonia and he was treated with multiple antibiotics.Â  While his condition initially improved, Willie died unexpectedly on August 30, 2000.Â  At the time of his death, Willie was forty-nine years old.Â  
An autopsy was performed on August 31, the day after Willieâ€™s death.Â  The autopsy, performed by Dr. Proctor, included in the case summary that microscopic evaluation of the lungs â€œrevealed a prominent interstitial fibrosis with superimposed bronchopneumonia and aspergillus.â€Â  The case summary further provided as follows:Â  â€œThese findings are consistent with a longstanding interstitial fibrosis with superimposed broncopneumonia and subsequent abscess formation.Â  The possibility that this superimposed pneumonia was chemical related cannot be excluded.â€Â  In the death summary dictated in October 2000, Willieâ€™s attending physician, Dr. Archambeau, stated cultures taken from Willie following his death â€œgrew out Aspergillusâ€ and he found Willieâ€™s cause of death was â€œ[l]ikely overwhelming sepsis from Aspergillus pneumonia.â€Â  He noted, however, the final cause of death would be determined by the autopsy.Â  
Carolyn presented the medical report of Dr. Harley to support her position that the ClO2 exposure induced the pneumonia that led to Willieâ€™s death.Â  Dr. Harley prepared an autopsy report in November 2000 finding the cause of Willieâ€™s death to be â€œ[s]epsis complicating pneumonia, lung abscess, and empyema, superimposed on severe chronic interstitial fibrosis of lungs.â€Â  He noted in his report, â€œIn putting this altogether, it would appear that Mr. Sargent had a chronic interstitial fibrosis. . . . This had probably been present for years.Â  Superimposed on this, he developed an acute bronchopneumonia which may have been related to chemical exposure.â€Â  Thereafter, on January 3, 2003, Dr. Harley submitted a medical report and opinion.Â  Dr. Harley noted that Willie had more longstanding lung disease than was appreciated before his death, and while the ClO2 exposure did not cause the fibrosis, it did â€œaggravate the already existing conditions.â€Â  He found the acute, probably bacterial pneumonia seen at autopsy, was most likely a superinfection secondary to an acute lung injury, and that lung injury was most probably from the ClO2 exposure.Â  He thus concluded, â€œit is my opinion that the record supports the conclusion that the ClO2 exposure was a cause for initiating the acute infectious process in this case, resulting in Mr. Sargentâ€™s death.â€Â  
International Paper countered with the opinions of Doctors Sahn, Proctor, Archambeau, and Russell, who all determined Willieâ€™s death was most likely unrelated to his exposure to the chemical.Â  Dr. Sahn noted Willieâ€™s history that he walked through an area three times in a ten minute period where ClO2 had been released into the air.Â  He observed that after Willie was admitted to the hospital, he was diagnosed with pneumonia and empyema, and eventually died with sepsis.Â  Dr. Sahn concluded, â€œ[A]fter review of the records and literature concerning chlorine inhalation, it is my opinion that the minimal and brief exposure to chlorine was unrelated to the development of a bacterial pneumonia and empyema several days later.â€Â  
Dr. Proctor indicated his autopsy evaluation revealed Willie had a severe underlying pulmonary fibrosis and he was at risk of developing pneumonia regardless of any chlorine exposure.Â  He noted the degree of fibrosis in Willieâ€™s lungs developed over a long period of time and led to â€œa serious compromise of his lung capacity and ability to clear his lungs.â€Â  Dr. Proctor concluded Willie had longstanding pulmonary fibrosis, he was at risk of developing infection without chemical exposure, and the â€œpneumonia most likely occurred as the result of his compromised pulmonary status rather than as a chemical induced pneumonia.â€Â  
Dr. Archambeau, Willieâ€™s attending physician, stated he was â€œin agreement with Dr. Sahnâ€™s report that [Willieâ€™s] problems leading to his death were probably not related to his alleged exposure to chlorine.â€Â  He opined that Willieâ€™s â€œprevious history of bullous emphysema and his diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia on admission led to the cause of his death.â€Â Â  
Finally, in November 2002, Dr. Roger Russell performed an extensive evaluation to determine whether the acute illness that led to Willieâ€™s death was an occupational disease or whether Willieâ€™s alleged chemical exposure exacerbated a preexisting condition, contributing to his demise.Â  In preparing his evaluation, Dr. Russell reviewed, among other things, Willieâ€™s hospital medical records, Dr. Proctorâ€™s autopsy report, Dr. Harleyâ€™s report, Willieâ€™s health records from International Paper, Willieâ€™s Pulmonary Function Test Results from 1989 to 1997, Dr. Sahnâ€™s report, and the various depositions of Carolyn Sargent and International Paper employees.Â  Dr. Russell noted the history given by Willie in the emergency room that he became short of breath approximately a week before, after passing through an area at work three times where there were ClO2 fumes.Â  Dr. Russell found the symptoms Willie complained of to the plant nurse clearly indicated â€œhe had a pneumonia caused by microorganisms as opposed to a chemical pneumontis.â€Â  He also observed the autopsy findings showed conclusively that Willie had extensive, chronic pulmonary fibrosis that predated the alleged chemical exposure and the fungal pneumonia of which Willie died.Â  Dr. Russell concluded as follows:

Mr. Willie Sargent had a severely compromised respiratory system, both from pulmonary fibrosis and from cigarette smoking.Â  He developed a mixed bacterial and fungal pneumonia, lung abscess, and empyema which responded in part to the removal of 600 cc of purulent fluid from the pleural space of his left lung and antibiotic therapy (antibiotics kill bacteria but not fungi).Â  He ultimately died from respiratory failure.Â  Fungi were first noted at autopsy and only identified weeks after his demise.Â  The pneumonia of which he died was caused by the introduction of microorganisms into his respiratory tract that his chronically diseased lungs were unable to clear.Â  Further, Mr. Sargent had a very shortened life expectancy due to the pulmonary fibrosis that was relentlessly converting his lungs into scar tissue.Â  He outlived the life expectancy of the average patient with pulmonary fibrosis.
In summary, it is my opinion within a reasonable degree of medical certainty that brief exposures to ClO2 fumes on or about August 17, 2000 would not have caused, aggravated, or accelerated the development of Mr. Sargentâ€™s pneumonia, lung abscess, and empyema since his natural lung defense mechanisms against microorganisms were completely destroyed long ago by cigarette smoke and pulmonary fibrosis.

Dr. Russellâ€™s opinion was unchanged after reading Dr. Harleyâ€™s January 3, 2003 report.Â  
The Single Commissioner made, inter alia, the following findings of fact:Â  (1) Willie was not exposed to any significant concentration of ClO2 as asserted by Carolyn, (2) at no time did Willie report any work related injury or accident to his employer, (3) Dr. Harleyâ€™s opinion carried little weight as it was based upon an inaccurate hypothetical set of facts, (4) the greater weight of the evidence in the record indicates Willieâ€™s death was not causally related to his employment or any alleged exposure to ClO2 and (5) Willie did not sustain an injury by accident arising out of and in the course of his employment.Â  Accordingly, the Commissioner determined Carolyn was not entitled to benefits.Â  
The Full Commission affirmed the Single Commissioner, adopting the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings in full.Â  Following a hearing on the matter, the circuit court found the decision of the Full Commission was supported by substantial evidence in the record and affirmed that decision.Â  This appeal follows.
ISSUES

  
    
      I. 
       Was the exclusion of evidence of an excited utterance by the employee conveying a present sense impression of why he was suffering from respiratory distress a clearly unwarranted abuse of discretion?
    
    
      II. 
       Was the exclusion of the opinion of the pathologist who performed the final autopsy in this case a clearly unwarranted abuse of discretion and the product of an error of law?
    
    
      III. 
       Was the finding below that there was no evidence of chemical exposure, reports of the exposure, or complaints about it the result of an error of law?
    
    
      IV.  
       Is the decision below clearly contrary to the substantial, reliable and probative evidence in the record when taken as a whole?
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981); Adkins v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 350 S.C. 34, 36-37, 564 S.E.2d 339, 340 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder and the final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is specifically reserved to the Full Commission.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  It is not the task of this Court to weigh the evidence as found by the Full Commission.Â  Id.Â  
In an appeal from the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, this court may reverse or modify a decision if the findings or conclusions of the commission are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  Neither this court nor the circuit court can substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  Id.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Exclusion of statement by employee
Carolyn first asserts error in the exclusion of a statement made by Willie to Davis on the last day the two men worked together.Â  The record shows that during the hearing before the Single Commissioner, counsel for Carolyn asked about the occasion Davis observed Willie â€œcoughing hard.â€Â  When counsel asked what Davis had said to Willie, Davis replied, â€œI asked him, I said, man, Willie, you are looking sort of bad.Â  Youâ€™re looking bad right now.Â  He said, man --.â€Â  At this point, counsel for International Paper objected.Â  Carolyn maintained the statement made at that time by Willie to Davis was a spontaneous utterance made in direct response to an inquiry and, as such, was an exception to the hearsay rule.Â  Unable to understand from the testimony â€œwhere [Willie] had just beenâ€ prior to the statement, the Commissioner sustained the objection.Â  During his deposition, Davis testified that Willieâ€™s response to Davisâ€™ expression of concern was, â€œI got gassed.â€Â  
On appeal, Carolyn argues the exclusion of the statement by Willie that he â€œgot gassedâ€ was an abuse of discretion in that the statement qualified as an exception to the hearsay rule under both the old rules, as a spontaneous utterance and thereby qualifying for admission under the res gestae exception, and the new rules as a present sense impression or excited utterance.Â  We do not need to determine whether the Commissioner erred in excluding this statement, however, as this statement was merely cumulative to other evidence that Willie may have sustained some exposure to ClO2.
First, Carolynâ€™s testimony before the Commissioner included that Willie had complained to her on Tuesday night about â€œinhaling the ClO2 gas.â€Â  Next, the record shows the nursing notes from Willieâ€™s admission to the hospital reflect Willie stated â€œClO2 â€“ bleaching agent â€“ was released into air last [Thursday]â€ and Willie â€œwent [through] area 3 times in 10 [minutes].â€Â  Further, consulting physician, Dr. Phillips, documented Willie informed him that â€œapproximately a week or so ago he was exposed to a chemical spill at the plant.Â  He describes this being a chloride-based bleach spill.â€Â  Finally, consulting physician, Dr. Felzien, also noted, â€œThe patient was initially involved in a chemical spill felt to be some type of chloride-based chemical approximately one week prior to admission.â€Â  
When evidence is erroneously excluded by the trial court, the appellate court first considers, among other things, whether the error may be deemed harmless because equivalent or cumulative evidence or testimony was offered.Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 31, 609 S.E.2d 506, 512 (2005).Â  The court also considers whether the aggrieved party managed to accomplish her primary objective, such as eliciting testimony about an issue or effectively cross-examining a witness.Â  Id. at 31-32, 609 S.E.2d at 512.Â  Additionally, the court considers whether, viewing the case as a whole, the excluded evidence or testimony was so crucial and important in proving the aggrieved partyâ€™s claim or defense that its exclusion constitutes prejudicial error.Â  Id.Â  at 32-33, 609 S.E.2d at 513.Â  Considering the evidence of record that Willie complained to his wife and to medical personnel of his exposure to ClO2, the statement by Willie to Davis that he had been â€œgassedâ€ was cumulative to the other evidence submitted on exposure to the chemical.Â  Further, Carolyn accomplished her primary objective of showing that Willie had complained of ClO2 exposure.Â  Finally, viewing the evidence as a whole, we are unpersuaded that this statement was so crucial to Carolynâ€™s claim that its exclusion constitutes reversible error.Â  The statement by Willie to Davis that he had been â€œgassedâ€ added nothing to the other evidence on exposure.Â  In his deposition testimony, Davis stated Willie did not give him any further information beyond the statement that he was â€œgassed.â€Â  Davis further testified in his deposition that, â€œwe all at one time or another have gotten gassedâ€ and â€œsome is worse than others.â€Â  This statement in no way elucidates the severity of the exposure.Â  Accordingly, we hold any error in the exclusion of this statement would be harmless and Carolyn suffered no prejudice by its exclusion.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Exclusion of opinion of pathologist
Carolyn next argues the exclusion of the opinion of Dr. Harley, who prepared the final autopsy in this case, was an abuse of discretion and based on an error of law.2Â  She asserts his opinion was excluded from consideration because it was allegedly based on a flawed hypothetical, and because Dr. Harleyâ€™s report was not based on a hypothetical but was based on the actual record in this case, his opinion should not have been disallowed.
In his findings of fact, the Single Commissioner found Willie was not exposed to â€œany significant concentration of ClO2â€ at the time in question.Â  The Commissioner concluded Dr. Harleyâ€™s opinion regarding causation necessarily assumed Willie was exposed to ClO2 and this assumption was not supported by the greater weight of the evidence.Â  Accordingly, the Commissioner determined Dr. Harleyâ€™s opinion regarding causation had little probative value and it was given little weight.Â  
First, it is clear the Commissioner did not exclude Dr. Harleyâ€™s opinion from evidence.Â  Rather, the Commissioner determined Dr. Harleyâ€™s opinion should be afforded little weight as Dr. Harley relied on the assumption Willie was in fact exposed to ClO2 on the date in question.Â  
We also note, reading the Commissionerâ€™s decision as a whole, it is clear the Commissioner found Carolyn failed to prove Willie was exposed to ClO2 as alleged on the date in question, and that if he was in fact exposed, â€œany exposure was fleetingâ€ and Willie â€œwas not exposed to any significant concentration of ClO2.â€Â  There is evidence of record that Willie failed to report any exposure to his employer at the time of the alleged incident and failed to report any exposure to the plant nurse a few days later when he went to first aid to complain of illness, in spite of the fact that Willie was a conscientious employee who knew protocol dictated he report an exposure.Â  Further, International Paper submitted evidence that Willie would not have been performing any major repairs on a mechanical problem, but was responsible only for reporting any such problems, and Willie specifically would not have been performing any repairs on a leak on the C line just prior to his coughing incident.Â  More importantly, Carolyn presented no evidence Willie â€œcaught a pretty good dose ofâ€ ClO2 while repairing a pump on the C line, as she maintained before the Commission.Â  
Neither this court nor the circuit court can substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  Further, the Full Commission adopted and incorporated the findings of the Single Commissioner.Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is specifically reserved to the Full Commission.Â  Considering the record as a whole, we find there is substantial evidence that would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached on the issue of Willieâ€™s exposure.Â  Even if the evidence were undisputed that Willie was in fact exposed to ClO2 on the date in question, there is substantial evidence of record that any exposure was minimal or â€œfleeting,â€ as Willie did not report the exposure to his employer at the time of exposure and also failed to report the exposure to the plant nurse several days later when complaining of illness.Â  
III.Â Â Â  Error of law in certain findings below 
Carolyn next asserts error in findings below that â€œthere was (a) no evidence of chemical exposure, (b) reports of that exposure or (c) complaints about it.â€Â  She argues, based on the record, these findings were an error of law.Â  We disagree.
We first note that Carolyn points to the following findings:

There is no competent evidence that [Willie] was exposed to ClO2, that he reported any exposure to ClO2, or that he complained of any work-related injury on or about August 19, 2000.Â  In fact, the substantial medical evidence in the record suggests [Willieâ€™s] death was not related to any alleged exposure to ClO2.

The findings of which Carolyn complains are findings made by the circuit court, not the Commission.Â  In an appeal from the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, this court reviews the decision of the Commission to determine whether the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Thus, the findings of the circuit court do not impact whether there is substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s decision.Â  The Commission found that the assumption Willie was exposed to ClO2 was not supported by the greater weight of the evidence, that Willie was not exposed to any significant concentration of ClO2 as asserted by Carolyn and, if he was in fact exposed, â€œany exposure was fleeting.â€Â  These findings are supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  
At any rate, considering the record as a whole, there is substantial evidence to support the findings of which Carolyn complains.Â  The record contains evidence that, had Willie been exposed as asserted by Carolyn, he was a conscientious employee who would have reported the exposure, and such exposure would have been well documented.Â  Thus, considering the record as a whole, there is evidence from which reasonable minds could have reached this conclusion.Â  Further, there is evidence of record that Willie did not report any exposure or complain of any exposure to his employer on the date in question, and these findings are likewise supported by substantial evidence.
IV.Â Â Â  Decisions below contrary to substantial, reliable, probative evidence
Lastly, Carolyn argues, because of specific erroneous findings, the findings of the Commission are not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.Â  
Carolyn asserts error in the Commissionâ€™s finding that Willie â€œhad not mentioned anything about any alleged exposure to ClO2 to his wife and did not complain of any unusual symptoms until Tuesday night, August 22, 2000.â€Â  Carolyn testified before the Commission that she first became aware Willie was having problems with his health on Sunday, when â€œ[h]e was coughing and he was aching all over.â€ Â However, she acknowledged she had stated in her deposition that the first time Willie complained to her was on Tuesday night, August 22, clarifying that was the first time Willie complained about â€œinhaling the ClO2 gas.â€Â  Accordingly, there is substantial evidence of record to support this finding.
Carolyn next complains of the Commissionâ€™s finding that while Davis testified he saw Willie coughing on the day in question, he â€œalways coughed a little.â€Â  She asserts this finding trivializes Davisâ€™ observation that he observed Willie coughing â€œhardâ€ on the day in question.Â  The Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Full Commission.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  The record shows, when asked whether he had ever seen him cough before in all the years he had known him, Davis testified Willie â€œalways coughed a little.â€Â  Thus, this finding is supported by substantial evidence of record.Â  Further, the Commission noted in its order that Davis also denied Willie coughed frequently or had shortness of breath.Â  Accordingly, the findings of the Commissioner do not support Carolynâ€™s argument that the Commissioner trivialized the evidence concerning Davisâ€™ observation of Willie coughing on the date in question.
Carolyn also asserts the Commissionâ€™s finding that Willieâ€™s job â€œinvolved reporting problems, but not fixing them,â€ is contrary to the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence of the record as a whole.Â  We disagree.Â  Carolyn is apparently referring to the Commissionâ€™s findings that â€œSmith testified [Willie] did not ever do any major repairs because [Willie] was a production worker and repairs were not part of his job function,â€ and that â€œ[a]pparently, [Willie] had no duties in connection with the in-line mixers on the C line.â€Â  Carolyn points to testimony from Smith that, when asked if Willie would perform minor repairs, he stated, â€œIf thereâ€™s something like a packing on a valve or something like that they do have a (sic) pliers where they can like pull up on a packing.â€Â  However, the evidence of record supports both of the findings by the Commission.Â  First, Smith did testify that in Willieâ€™s capacity as a Service Operator I, he never performed any major repairs, as it was not part of his job function.Â  Further, when discussing the in-line mixer on the C Line, Smith was asked if it was correct that if a problem were reported on the mixer, a mechanic would have performed all of the repair work.Â  Smith stated, â€œRight, and the repair work for a mixer leak would be to change out the mixer.Â  And not to go do something, you know, to temporarily fix it.Â  Itâ€™s just not a temporary fix.â€Â  Additionally, Davis testified that if there were any problems on the jobs they checked, they normally would not fix anything, but would just report the problem, and stated Willie would not have been performing any repairs on a leak on the C Line when he was called away.Â  Accordingly, considering the record as a whole, there is substantial evidence supporting the Commissionâ€™s findings.
Carolyn next argues the Commissionâ€™s finding that no chemical exposure occurred since there was â€œno particular incident reportâ€ in the file detailing a chemical exposure was improper.Â  She contends the absence of a company-generated report is â€œentirely neutralâ€ and therefore neither supports nor refutes an inference that a chemical exposure occurred.Â  We disagree.Â  The record contains evidence that Willie failed to report any exposure to either his employer at the time of the alleged exposure or to the plant nurse days after the alleged exposure when he sought treatment for his illness.Â  Further, there is evidence of record that Willie was a conscientious employee who would have reported an exposure to a chemical.Â  The weight to be attributed to this evidence in determining whether Willie was exposed to ClO2 as claimed by Carolyn is reserved for the Commission and we will not substitute our judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.
Carolyn next contends the Commission erroneously found an employee, Mr. Lance, performed regularly scheduled maintenance on the C Line mixer on August 25, 2000 and found no problems with the valves and he did not have to perform or schedule any repairs because â€œeverything worked.â€Â  She argues this finding distorts reality by suggesting there could not have been any ClO2 leaks from the C Line mixer on August 18, 2000, when there was evidence the mixer had been replaced on August 24, 2000.Â  We first note the Commissionâ€™s order in this respect appears to merely summarize the testimony of employee John Lance, and therefrom finds, â€œMr. Lanceâ€™s testimony does not support the Claimantâ€™s allegations that [Willie] was exposed to ClO2 on August 19, 2000 or at any other time.â€Â  It does not find there could not have been a ClO2 leak from the C Line on August 18, 2000.Â  At any rate, Carolyn failed to include any testimony from Mr. Lance in the record on appeal.Â  Therefore this court has no way of reviewing the matter to determine whether there was any error in the Commissionâ€™s order with respect to Mr. Lanceâ€™s testimony.Â  See Crestwood Golf Club, Inc. v. Potter, 328 S.C. 201, 215, 493 S.E.2d 826, 834 (1997)Â  (noting the appealing party has the burden of providing a sufficient record to allow consideration of an issue).
Finally, Carolyn contends the Commission erroneously relied on the opinions of International Paperâ€™s medical experts in finding that Willieâ€™s death was the result of his compromised pulmonary status.Â  She argues the fact that Willieâ€™s pulmonary condition was compromised did not necessarily lead to the conclusion that his death was not compensable, and that the opinions of the companyâ€™s medical experts should have been discounted because they erroneously relied on a flawed hypothetical that assumed Willie had not inhaled any ClO2 at all.Â  We disagree.
In order to be entitled to compensation for an injury under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, a claimant must show he suffered an â€œinjury by accident arising out of and in the course of the employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2004). Â The term â€œarising out ofâ€ refers to the origin of the cause of the accident.Â  Harrell v. Pineland Plantation, Ltd., 337 S.C. 313, 323, 523 S.E.2d 766, 771 (1999).Â  An accidental injury is considered to arise out of oneâ€™s employment when there is a causal connection between the conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting injury.Â  Id. at 324, 523 S.E.2d at 771.
First, we have already found there is substantial evidence that would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Commission reached that Carolyn failed to prove Willie was exposed to ClO2 as alleged.Â  There is also substantial evidence of record that, even if the evidence were undisputed that Willie was in fact exposed to ClO2 on the date in question, any exposure was minimal or fleeting.Â  At any rate, a review of the record fails to show these doctors â€œsimply assume[d] that [Willie] had not inhaled any ClO2 at allâ€ as asserted by Carolyn.Â  To the contrary, these doctors all agreed that it was unlikely Willieâ€™s death was related to the alleged chemical exposure, and clearly took into account Willieâ€™s possible exposure to ClO2.Â  
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
2 Carolyn refers to Dr. Harleyâ€™s report as the â€œfinal autopsy.â€Â  The record shows Dr. Proctor performed an autopsy on Willie on August 31, 2000, and that Dr. Harley subsequently prepared an autopsy report after receiving certain body tissue from Dr. Proctor and apparently reviewing Dr. Proctorâ€™s report.Â

title: Lewis-Murray v. Murray
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Carolyn M. Lewis-Murray, Respondent,
v.
Perry L. Murray, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Wayne M. Creech, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-555
Heard October 5, 2005 â€“ Filed October 17, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Susan Trout Kinard, of Mt. Pleasant; for Appellant.
John B. Williams, of Moncks Corner; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Perry L. Murray (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order denying his motion to vacate the partiesâ€™ final decree of divorce and for a new trial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Carolyn M. Lewis-Murray (Wife) were married on October 19, 1997.Â  Prior to the marriage, Husband experienced health problems resulting from heart disease.Â  On October 22, 1997, Husband underwent heart surgery and was subsequently prescribed medication to treat this condition as well as depression.Â  Following his surgery, Husband moved into Wifeâ€™s home in order to recover.Â  After several weeks, Husband moved out of Wifeâ€™s home and into a garage apartment that was attached to a house that Husband was building.Â  The circumstances surrounding Husbandâ€™s decision to move are disputed by the parties.Â  Husband claimed that Wife had no interest in caring for him and made his life intolerable.Â  In contrast, Wife asserted Husband had been unfaithful to her during the marriage.
As an apparent result of this marital discord, the parties entered into a separation and property settlement agreement (Agreement) on October 21, 1998.Â  Husband asserted he signed it under duress because Wife threatened him regarding his alleged extra-marital affair.Â  He further contended he was also under the influence of medication when he signed the Agreement.Â  Pursuant to the Agreement, the parties equitably divided the marital debts and property.Â  Significantly, Wife was granted the house that Husband claimed he built for his retirement and to provide for his extended family.Â  As part of the Agreement, Husband was permitted to reside in the garage apartment for six months after the parties executed the Agreement.Â  According to Husband, Wife and members of her family had at this point moved into the residence.
On February 8, 1999, Wife filed a summons and complaint, seeking a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation and requesting the family court approve the Agreement and incorporate it into the final decree of divorce.Â  Although Husband contends he has no recollection of responding to Wifeâ€™s pleadings, a pro se Answer was filed on February 19, 1999.
At the hearing before the family court on March 12, 1999, Wife was present and represented by counsel.Â  Husband, who later claimed he had no notice of the hearing, was not present nor did counsel represent him.Â  By order dated March 18, 1999, the family court granted Wife a divorce and approved the Agreement.Â  A written acknowledgment of service dated March 31, 1999, and filed April 7, 1999, indicated Husband received a copy of the family courtâ€™s order. 
On May 5, 2003, Husband moved to have the divorce decree vacated and to be granted a new trial.Â  Although Husband generally moved for relief from judgment, he specifically claimed:Â  (1) he did not receive notice of the divorce hearing nor did he receive notice of the issuance of the final order; (2) he was mentally and physically incapacitated prior to and at the time of the hearing; (3) he signed the Agreement under duress; and (4) the family court approved the Agreement despite the courtâ€™s failure to question him regarding whether the Agreement was fair and entered into voluntarily.Â  In support of his motion, Husband submitted an affidavit, a letter from a treating physician, and a memorandum of law.Â  Additionally, Husband explained he had delayed in filing the motion because he only recently became aware of the existence of the final divorce decree when he attempted to use a credit line that was secured by the house that he had built.
After Wife filed a return to the motion in which she disputed Husbandâ€™s allegations, the family court held a hearing.Â  By order dated November 5, 2003, the family court denied Husbandâ€™s motion, finding it was untimely given Husband had â€œwaited more than four years after the service of the Final Decree of Divorce before he . . . raised any issue as to the validity of the Decree.â€Â  However, despite this holding, the court noted that the absence of a receipt of notice of the final hearing and Husbandâ€™s alleged competency issues may have served as a basis to challenge the decree of divorce.Â  Husband appeals.
DISCUSSION
Husband argues the family court erred in denying his motion to set aside the final divorce decree.Â  In support of this argument, Husband raises two grounds.Â  First, he claims the final order was procured through fraud given he was physically and mentally incapacitated prior to and at the time of the final hearing.Â  Secondly, he asserts the order was void because he was never served with Wifeâ€™s summons and complaint or with the family courtâ€™s final decree of divorce.Â  
Rule 60 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure governs this case.Â  Subsection (b), the pertinent provision, provides as follows:

  
    
      
        (b) 
         Mistakes; Inadvertence; Excusable Neglect; Newly Discovered Evidence; Fraud, etc.Â  On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:
      
      
        
         
      
      
        (1) 
         mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect;
      
      
        (2) 
         newly discovered evidence which by due diligence could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial under Rule 59(b);
      
      
        (3) 
         fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party;
      
      
        (4)  
         the judgment is void;
      
      
        (5)
         the judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged, or a prior judgment upon which it is based has been reversed or otherwise vacated, or it is no longer equitable that the judgment should have prospective application.
      
    
  
The motion shall be made within a reasonable time, and for reasons (1), (2), and (3) not more than one year after the judgment, order or proceeding was entered or taken.Â  A motion under this subdivision (b) does not affect the finality of a judgment or suspend its operation.Â  This rule does not limit the power of a court to entertain an independent action to relieve a party from a judgment, order, or proceeding, or to set aside a judgment for fraud upon the court.

Rule 60(b), SCRCP.
â€œA party seeking to set aside a judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b) has the burden of presenting evidence entitling him to the requested relief.â€ Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 215, 612 S.E.2d 456, 458 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Whether to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b) lies within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Raby Constr., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 17, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 (2004).Â  Therefore, our review is confined to determining whether the family court abused its discretion in granting or denying the motion.Â  Lanier, 364 S.C. at 216, 612 S.E.2d at 458.
As a threshold matter, we note neither Husband nor the court identified which subsections of Rule 60 formed the basis of the motion and the subsequent ruling.Â  Given this procedural posture, it is difficult to discern the exact grounds for the courtâ€™s decision.Â  However, even assuming Husbandâ€™s claims of intrinsic fraud and the invalidity of the order were meritorious,[1] we agree with the family court that any motion to set aside the final order was untimely under either the one-year Rule 60(b)(3) subsection or the (4) and (5) â€œreasonable timeâ€ subsections.Â  
Clearly, Husbandâ€™s claim filed approximately four and a half years after the final order could only be conceivably argued under the â€œreasonable timeâ€ subsections (4) and (5).Â  Based on the specific facts of this case, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in finding the motion was untimely, i.e., the delay could not be construed as â€œreasonable.â€ See Smith Cos. of Greenville v. Hayes, 311 S.C. 358, 359, 428 S.E.2d 900, 902 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œUnder Rule 60(b)(4) and (5), the court may grant a party relief from judgment if the party makes a motion seeking relief within a reasonable time.â€).
Although Husband contends he did not receive notice of the final divorce decree, there is evidence in the record in the form of an acknowledgment of service that Husband received a copy of the final decree of divorce on March 31, 1999.Â  As to allegations that Husband was physically and mentally incapacitated for a period of time due to his health problems, we find no evidence in the record that these problems would have prevented him from filing a timely motion to be relieved from judgment.Â  Significantly, Husband retained his position as Chief Magistrate for Berkeley County despite his health problems.Â  Moreover, we cannot glean from the record that Husbandâ€™s health problems extended far beyond the time period prior to and at the time of the divorce hearing.[2]Â  In fact, Husbandâ€™s motion to set aside the judgment, which included his affidavit, does not address any time period after the decree was issued. See Perry v. Heirs at Law of Gadsden, 357 S.C. 42, 48, 590 S.E.2d 502, 505 (Ct. App. 2003)(citations omitted) (â€œ[A]lthough motions under Rule 60(b)(5) are not subject to the requirement that they be filed within one year of the judgment, they still must be filed within a reasonable time.Â  While we are reluctant to proclaim that four years is a per se unreasonable period of time, [defendant], who bore the burden of showing the propriety of his motion, has failed to proffer an argument as to why we should find the four-year delay is reasonable in this case.â€); McDaniel v. United States Fidelity & Guar. Co., 324 S.C. 639, 644, 478 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding trial court properly denied partyâ€™s motion to set aside judgment as void pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP where motion was not filed within a reasonable time given motion was filed after nearly four years and party participated in the settlement and received substantial benefits from it).
Finally, to the extent Husband argues the Agreement was procured and approved through extrinsic fraud, and thus infinitely extended his time to file a Rule 60(b) motion, we find this issue not properly before this court. See Raby Constr., L.L.P., 358 S.C. at 19, 594 S.E.2d at 483 (â€œExtrinsic fraud is â€˜fraud that induces a person not to present a case or deprives a person of the opportunity to be heard.â€™â€ (quoting Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., 354 S.C. 72, 81, 579 S.E.2d 605, 610 (2003)); Chewning, 354 S.C. at 80, 579 S.E.2d at 609-10 (â€œThere is no statute of limitations when a party seeks to set aside a judgment due to fraud upon the court.â€).Â  
First, the family court did not make a determination whether extrinsic fraud was involved, but instead denied Husbandâ€™s motion on the sole ground that it was untimely.Â  Secondly, Husband failed to file a motion to reconsider in order to obtain a specific ruling on the allegation of extrinsic fraud. See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 43, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997) (stating where a trial court did not rule on issue at trial and party did not make a motion pursuant to Rule 59 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, issue was not preserved for appellate review); see also Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (stating that when a trial court makes a general ruling on an issue, but a party does not make a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to obtain a ruling on the argument, the appellate court cannot consider the argument on appeal). 
Based on the foregoing, the circuit courtâ€™s denial of Husbandâ€™s motion for relief from judgment is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  â€œIntrinsic fraud refers to fraud presented and considered in the judgment assailed, including perjury and forged documents presented at trial.â€Â  Evans v. Gunter, 294 S.C. 525, 529, 366 S.E.2d 44, 46 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œA void judgment is one that, from its inception, is a complete nullity and is without legal effect.Â  The definition of void under the rule only encompasses judgments from courts which failed to provide proper due process, or judgments from courts which lacked subject matter jurisdiction or personal jurisdiction.â€ Universal Benefits, Inc. v. McKinney, 349 S.C. 179, 183, 561 S.E.2d 659, 661 (Ct. App. 2002)(citations omitted).
[2]Â  Husband does assert in his brief that his medical condition â€œcaused him to be unable to reason effectively or to defend himself throughout the period his domestic action was pending and for an extended period thereafter.â€Â  However, this assertion is not supported by any documentation and is vague at best.

title: Russell Corporation v. Gregg
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Russell Corporation, Appellant,
v.
William M. Gregg, II, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-556
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 17, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Lawrence W. Johnson, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Harry A. Swagart, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Russell Corporation appeals a trial courtâ€™s decision granting summary judgment to William M. Gregg, II, and finding Gregg was released from his liability for South Carolina Teesâ€™ debts by rescinding his personal guaranty.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
In July 1985, William Gregg signed a continuing guaranty on behalf of South Carolina Tees, Incorporated, in order for his company to secure merchandise from Russell Corporation.Â  The guaranty was subject to interpretation under the laws of the State of Alabama, and was â€œa continuing guaranty and shall continue in full force and effect . . . until the full performance, payment, and discharge of all said Customer Obligations, and thereafter until actual receipt by [Russell] from [Gregg] of written notice of cancellation.â€Â  (Emphasis added).
In May 1998, Michael Thaxton, Russellâ€™s Manager of Credit and Accounts Receivable, wrote to Gregg to inform him that the continuing guaranty was not affected by South Carolina Teesâ€™ change of address.Â  On May 8, 1998, Gregg responded in a letter, which states:Â  â€œIn response to your letter dated May 2, 1998, the guaranty you quote was revoked at least five years ago.â€Â  Thaxton responded by inclosing a copy of the guaranty with a letter stating:Â  â€œYou will note that revocation of this guarantee can only be accomplished through written notice to our offices.Â  We have no such written notice therefore the guarantee is enforceable.â€Â  
On December 27, 2002, Russell filed a complaint against Gregg seeking to enforce the continuing guaranty and collect amounts owed on behalf of South Carolina Tees.Â  Gregg denied the guaranty was still in effect.Â  The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment.Â  Gregg maintained Russell â€œdispensed with the requirement of a personal guaranty after 1992â€ or â€œthat [Gregg] cancelled his guaranty in accordance with the terms thereof.â€Â  
Each party provided affidavit and deposition testimony in support of the motions for summary judgment.Â  Gregg presented his affidavit as well as that of David Young to support the claim that he was released by Russell in 1992.Â  In Greggâ€™s affidavit, he states that in 1992 he contacted Young regarding the guaranty and was subsequently released from any further guaranties.Â  Gregg also stated that Young called Sally Lambeth (now Hornsby) and she verified that the guaranty was in Russellâ€™s cancelled guaranty file.Â  Youngâ€™s affidavit also indicates that in 1992 the guaranty was orally cancelled at the request of Gregg.Â  
Russell put forth the affidavits of Sally Lambeth Hornsby and Michael Thaxton, who replaced Young at Russell when Young went to work for Gregg, as well as Thaxtonâ€™s deposition.Â  In his deposition, Thaxton indicated he never found any written notice of the revocation of the guaranty in Russellâ€™s files.Â  He also stated Russellâ€™s position was that the guaranty was still in effect.Â  
In his affidavit, Thaxton described Russellâ€™s policy when a guaranty is cancelled.Â  He stated the guaranty would have been returned to Gregg and that there is no canceled guaranty file as indicated in Greggâ€™s affidavit.Â  Additionally, he stated that Russell would have completed additional evaluation of the credit position of South Carolina Tees when Gregg was released.Â  He indicated there was no evidence in Russellâ€™s files of the evaluation.Â  Finally, he stated that the policies of Russell are the same ones that were in effect when Young was employed by Russell and have not changed.Â  
Sally Hornsby indicated in her affidavit that from 1993 through 2000, Greggâ€™s guaranty remained in full effect.Â  She stated that she never informed Young or anyone else that the guaranty was revoked or canceled.Â  Finally, she stated the policy of Russell was to return the original guaranty to the guarantor and place a copy in the credit file indicating it had been revoked.Â  
The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Gregg, finding the affidavits and testimony by Thaxton and Hornsby were insufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact regarding whether the guaranty was revoked.Â  The court held that testimony regarding Russellâ€™s procedures and the fact the procedures were not followed was insufficient to create a genuine issue of fact.Â  The court further concluded that even if the guaranty was not revoked in 1992, the letter by Gregg indicating his belief the guaranty was revoked was sufficient notice to Russell to cancel the guaranty.Â  As all obligations sought to be collected by Russell occurred after 1998, the court concluded Gregg was not liable on his guaranty and was entitled to summary judgment.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court:Â  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Russell maintains the court erred in granting summary judgment to Gregg because there was a genuine issue of material fact with regards to whether the guaranty was canceled in 1992.Â  Additionally, Russell contends the court erred in finding Greggâ€™s 1998 letter sufficient to constitute written notice of the revocation of the guaranty under Alabama law.Â  We agree.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  1992 Revocation
Russell asserts Thaxtonâ€™s deposition as well as the affidavits by Thaxton and Hornsby create a genuine issue of material fact regarding whether Gregg properly revoked his guaranty in 1992.Â Â  We agree and find summary judgment was inappropriate.Â  
If triable issues exist, those issues must be submitted to the jury.Â  Young v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 718, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Even where no dispute as to evidentiary facts exists, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should not be granted.Â  Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 173-74, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Moreover, summary judgment is a drastic remedy that should be cautiously invoked to ensure no person is improperly deprived of a trial of disputed factual issues.Â  Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of S.C., 349 S.C. 356, 363, 563 S.E.2d 331, 334 (2002).
In the current case, the guaranty specifically provided it â€œshall continue in full force and effect . . . until the full performance, payment, and discharge of all said Customer Obligations, and thereafter until actual receipt by [Russell] from [Gregg] of written notice of cancellation.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  Neither Youngâ€™s nor Greggâ€™s affidavit indicated Gregg supplied written notice of his intention to cancel the guaranty.Â  
Additionally, Thaxtonâ€™s affidavit creates a genuine issue of material fact because he indicates Russellâ€™s files did not show a cancellation.Â  Thaxton indicated Young established the procedures to be followed when a guaranty is cancelled.Â  He testified that none of the procedures, including sending the guaranty back to the guarantor or performing a follow-up credit review, were noted in Russellâ€™s file.Â  Finally, Hornsby indicated the guaranty was still in effect as it was the entire time she was in her position, which was from 1993 until 2000.Â  She also testified regarding the proper procedures when a guaranty is revoked and noted that none of these were followed for Gregg. 
Accordingly, we believe Russell submitted sufficient evidence to indicate the cancellation provision of the guaranty was not complied with in 1992.Â  In addition, there was evidence from which a jury could determine the guaranty was not revoked but was still in effect.Â  Therefore, the court erred in granting summary judgment to Gregg based on his alleged revocation in 1992.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  1998 Revocation
Russell contends the trial court erred in finding Greggâ€™s 1998 letter constituted sufficient notice to cancel the guaranty.Â  We agree and find that under Alabama law, whether the letter was sufficient was a question of fact for a jury to determine.
In Livingston v. Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, 176 S.C. 385, 180 S.E. 343 (1935), our Supreme Court discussed the traditional choice of law provision for contracts:

It is fundamental that unless there be something intrinsic in, or extrinsic of, the contract that another place of enforcement was intended, the lex loci contractu governs.Â  If the contract be silent thereabout, the presumption is that the law governing the enforcement is the law of the place where the contract is made.

Livingston, 180 S.E. at 345.
In the instant case, the guaranty specifically states it â€œshall be interpreted according to the laws of the State of Alabama.â€Â  Accordingly, we look to Alabama law to determine whether Greggâ€™s 1998 letter satisfies the written notification requirement of the guarantee.
In Sharer v. Bend Millwork Systems, Inc., 600 So.2d 223 (Ala. 1992), the Alabama Supreme Court held a written notice requirement was not satisfied where the creditor had actual notice that the guarantor was no longer affiliated with the borrower.Â  However, in that case, there was no allegation of any writing.Â  Sharer simply alleged the creditor had notice of his intentions to be relieved and that he no longer was involved in the company for which he had executed the guaranty.Â  Id. at 226-227.
However, in Lightsey v. Orgill Brothers and Company, Inc., 454 So.2d 1002 (Ala. Civ. App. 1984), the court found:

It is settled law that â€œ[a] promise of guaranty Â·Â·Â· is revocable like other offers.â€ 1 A. Corbin, Corbin on Contracts Â§ 38 (1963). â€œThe method of exercising this power [of revocation] varies; usually it is by giving notice to the offeree.â€ 1 A.Corbin, Corbin on Contracts Â§ 38 (1963).
It is settled law in Alabama that â€œ[c]ontracting parties are free to modify their contract by mutual assent.â€ Kinmon v. J.P. King Auction Co., 290 Ala. 323, 276 So.2d 569 (1973). And, since mutual assent is a factual issue, it must be determined by the jury. Cook v. Sweatt, 282 Ala. 177, 209 So.2d 891 (1965).Â Â Â Â Â  

Lightsey, 454 So.2d at 1005.
In Lightsey, the guarantor notified the creditor that they no longer owned the company for which they executed the guaranty.Â  The creditor required them to write a letter advising it of the sale.Â  The letter was written advising of the sale, but did not specifically revoke the personal guaranty.Â  The Alabama court found there was evidence from which the jury could determine whether the letter was sufficient to revoke the personal guaranty.Â  Id. at 1005-06.
The writing in the case sub judice does not specifically revoke the guaranty, nor does it expressly notify Russell that Greggâ€™s intention was to revoke the guaranty.Â  In addition, Thaxton explained that a written revocation was necessary to comply with guarantyâ€™s provisions.Â  It is undisputed that Gregg never offered additional written notice of his revocation.Â  Accordingly, the issue of whether the letter was sufficient notice of Greggâ€™s intent to revoke the guaranty should have been submitted to the jury for consideration.Â  Therefore, the court erred in granting summary judgment to Gregg.[1]
CONCLUSION
We find there was evidence presented from which a jury could determine Gregg did not properly cancel his personal guaranty in 1992.Â  Additionally, under Alabama law, whether the 1998 letter was sufficient notice to cancel the guaranty is a question for the jury.Â  Therefore, we find the court improperly granted summary judgment to Gregg.Â  The decision of the court is 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.  [2]
ANDERSON, J., HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Russell also argues the court erred to the extent the order can be read to find Russell was estopped from enforcing the guaranty.Â  We agree.Â  Estoppel is an affirmative defense.Â  Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas Horiz. Prop. Regime, 307 S.C. 339, 345, 415 S.E.2d 384, 388 (1992).Â Â  It was not pled in this case, and was therefore waived.Â  See Howard v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways, 343 S.C. 149, 155, 538 S.E.2d 291, 294 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The order of the trial court is also reversed to the extent it can be read to grant summary judgment based upon a theory of estoppel. 
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Screening Report / Proposed Opinion


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Alexander Mickle, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-557
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 17, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, of Columbia, and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Alexander Mickle appeals a conviction for first-degree burglary arguing the trial court erred in admitting evidence of twelve prior burglary convictions in the Stateâ€™s case in chief.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On March 22, 2003, Ramzi Ahmed and his roommate, Hafez Muharad, decided to relax after work by shooting pool at a local bar.Â  After spending a couple of hours so occupied, they returned to their Meeting Street apartment in Charleston sometime around 2:00 a.m.Â  As they approached the residence, they noticed a car parked across the street and a man standing by the car closing the trunk.Â  About the same time, the roommates noticed that the front door to their apartment was open.Â  
Suspecting foul play, they walked over to the car and noticed several of their belongings were inside.Â  After being confronted, the driver of the car, who was later identified as Alexander Mickle, quickly jumped in the car and attempted to leave the scene. Â Before he could do so, however, Ramzi Ahmed reached into the car and took the keys out of the ignition.Â  Having prevented Mickle from leaving, Ramzi and Hafez called 911.Â  When Mickle noticed the police were being called, he began to take their belongings out of the car and return them to the apartment.[1]Â  
Ramzi Ahmed testified that after Mickle returned the items to the home, he tried to get the roommates to let him leave, stating that since they once again had their belongings no harm was done.Â  When the police arrived a short time later, Mickle was still at the residence.Â  After talking to the roommates, the officer attempted to talk to Mickle alone near his patrol car.Â  Because Mickle was acting â€œagitated and nervousâ€ the officer decided to conduct a protective pat-down search to ensure Mickle was not carrying a weapon.Â  
When the officer attempted to search Mickleâ€™s waist area, Mickle reached into his waistband and produced a tire iron.Â  As he raised the tire iron, the officer grabbed Mickle in a bear hug and the two struggled until the tire iron was dropped.Â  The officer told Mickle to stop resisting or he would release his canine.Â  Mickle, however, broke free and began to flee the scene.Â  The officer then released his canine and a short time later Mickle was subdued.Â  On Mickleâ€™s person, the officer found a copy of the Holy Koran, which belonged to Hafez
Muharad.  
Having secured Mickle, the officer did a survey of the house and noticed that the apartment was in a state of disarray, and that the victimsâ€™ property was strewn all over.Â  He further observed pry marks between the door and the doorframe where the house was broken into.Â  When the crime scene was processed a short time later, a number of fingerprints were lifted from various items in the house and molds were taken of the pry marks on the doorframe.Â  
At trial, an officer testified that Mickleâ€™s fingerprint was found on a cigar box, which allegedly was one of the items that Mickle returned to the house after the victims returned home.Â  Another officer testified that the pry marks were consistent with the tire iron found on Mickleâ€™s person that evening. 
Mickleâ€™s defense consisted of his testimony that earlier in the evening on the night in question, he met a man at a local bar whom he called â€œBrother Man,â€ until he later found out his name was either â€œNookieâ€ or â€œRookie.â€Â  Mickle stated that he talked to this man for a while at the bar about working for him in his contracting business.Â  They left the bar around 1:30 a.m. at which time Mickle decided he would help this man pick up some of his belongings.Â  They went to what Mickle thought was the manâ€™s home and Mickle testified that he sat in the car while the man made trips to and from the house loading the car with various items.Â  Mickle stated that he became suspicious of him after he began slamming the trunk and asking whether Mickle was interested in purchasing some of the items.Â  Sensing that Mickle was suspicious, he walked away shortly before the homeâ€™s actual residents arrived.Â  
Following trial, the jury convicted Mickle of burglary in the first degree, assault of a high and aggravated nature, grand larceny and assault while resisting arrest.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
Mickle argues the trial court erred in allowing the state to introduce evidence of twelve prior burglary convictions in its case in chief to support the charge of burglary in the first degree. 
Burglary in the first degree is defined by statute as follows:

  
    
      
        (A) 
         A person is guilty of burglary in the first degree if the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime in the dwelling, and either:
      
      
        
        (1) 
         when, in effecting entry or while in the dwelling or in immediate flight, he or another participant in the crime:
      
      
        
        
        
          
            
              (a) 
               is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive; or
            
            
              (b) 
               causes physical injury to a person who is not a participant in the crime; or
            
            
              (c)
              uses or threatens the use of a dangerous instrument; or
            
            
              (d) 
               displays what is or appears to be a knife, pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, machine gun, or other firearm; or
            
          
        
      
      
        
        (2) 
         the burglary is committed by a person with a prior record of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a combination of both; or
      
      
        
        (3) 
         the entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.
      
    
  

. . . .
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (2003).
To support the first-degree burglary charge, the State relied on both the fact that entry occurred in the nighttime and that Mickle had a record of two or more burglary convictions.Â  In fact, Mickle had twelve prior burglary convictions, four for grand larceny, five for receiving stolen goods, and one conviction for breaking and entering of a motor vehicle.Â  
In a pre-trial conference, Mickle objected to the use of all twelve burglary convictions.Â  Specifically, defense counsel asked that all of the burglary convictions be excluded based on State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923), Rules 609 and 404(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence, and fundamental fairness concerns.Â  In the alternative, counsel asked that the number of convictions admitted be limited to two.
After hearing arguments from both sides, the trial court ruled that based on State v. Cheatham, 349 S.C. 101, 561 S.E.2d 618 (Ct. App. 2002) and State v. James, 346 S.C. 303, 551 S.E.2d 591 (Ct. App. 2002), the State could not be required to limit the number of burglary convictions used because the statute does not contain such a restriction.Â  The court further held that because it would issue a curative instruction informing the jury of the limited purpose of the convictions, Mickle would not be prejudiced by their admission.Â  
Prior to this ruling, Mickle informed the court that should it rule against him, he would enter into a stipulation with the State as to the existence of all 12 burglaries.Â  Accordingly, during the Stateâ€™s case in chief, a stipulation was read into evidence outlining Mickleâ€™s prior convictions for burglary.Â  As such, Mickle did not object at the time the convictions were entered into the record.Â  
Although Mickleâ€™s position is supported by our supreme courtâ€™s ruling in State v. James, 355 S.C. 25, 583 S.E.2d 745 (2003) (overruling this courtâ€™s decision in State v. James, 346 S.C. 303, 551 S.E.2d 591 (Ct. App. 2002) and holding admission of seven prior burglary convictions was error where the trial court did not conduct an analysis to determine whether the probative value of said convictions outweighed their prejudicial effect), he failed to preserve the issue for our review.Â  It is well settled that a motion in limine to exclude evidence at the start of trial does not preserve an issue for review unless the moving party makes a contemporaneous objection when the evidence is introduced.Â  See e.g., State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 526, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Rather than object when the convictions were offered, Mickle stipulated to their existence; as such, we find the issue to be unpreserved.
Even if the issue was correctly preserved, it would fail on the merits.Â  Although the trial court in the current case failed to conduct an analysis as required by our supreme courtâ€™s decision in James, considering the significant amount of evidence against Mickle, we find any error by the trial court was harmless.Â  See State v. Keenon, 356 S.C. 457, 459, 590 S.E.2d 34-5 (2003) (finding that â€œbecause of the overwhelming evidence of petitionerâ€™s guilt . . . the admission of more than two prior convictions was harmless error.â€).
Mickle also argues the trial court erred in failing to conduct an analysis to determine if admission of Mickleâ€™s prior crimes would be more prejudicial than probative before admitting them under 609(a)(2), SCRE.Â  We disagree.
Rule 609, SCRE reads as follows: 

(a) General Rule.Â  For the purposes of attacking the credibility of a witness, 
(1) evidence that a witness other than an accused has been convicted of a crime shall be admitted, subject to Rule 403, if the crime was punishable by death or imprisonment in excess of one year under the law under which the witness was convicted, and evidence that an accused has been convicted of such a crime shall be admitted if the court determines that the probative value of admitting this evidence outweighs its prejudicial effect to the accused; and
(2) evidence that any witness has been convicted of a crime shall be admitted if it involved dishonesty or false statement, regardless of the punishment.

Significantly, Mickle does not dispute whether the convictions admitted were crimes of dishonesty.Â  Mickleâ€™s sole argument is that the trial court should have conducted a prejudicial analysis before admitting the convictions for impeachment purposes. 
In State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 578 S.E.2d 32 (Ct. App. 2003) we addressed this precise issue.Â  After deciding in that case that armed robbery was a crime of dishonesty under Rule 609(a)(2), we articulated the following holding:

Rule 609(a)(2) provides for automatic admission of evidence of a prior crime of dishonesty without the balancing of probative value against prejudicial effect.Â  This conclusion is supported by the juxtaposition of Rule 609(a)(1) and Rule 609(a)(2).Â  There is absolutely no language in Rule 609(a)(2) compelling a balancing test for admission in regard to a crime of dishonesty.

Al-Amin at 426, 578 S.E.2d at 43.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in allowing admission of Mickleâ€™s prior crimes of dishonesty.
 AFFIRMED. [2]
ANDERSON, J., HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Hafez Muharad testified that the value of the items taken was approximately $2,000 and included, inter alia, two radios, three jackets, shoes, a suit, binoculars, and a compact disc player.Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
