text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Roger L. Arbogast, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-558
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 24, 2005Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James Arthur Brown, Jr., of Beaufort and James Wofford Bannister, of Greenville, for Appellant. 
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Roger Lee Arbogast was convicted of trafficking in opium and distribution of Tylenol Four with codeine and sentenced to an aggregate term of 25 years in prison.Â  Arbogast appeals, arguing the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict for him, violating his due process rights, and charging the jury incorrectly.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
An informant for the Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s Department contacted Arbogast requesting to purchase from him opium and Tylenol Four with codeine and sell him marijuana.Â  On March 26, 2002, Arbogast sold an undercover officer, who was accompanying the informant, a half full bottle of opium and a bottle of 101 Tylenol Four pills for $225.Â  Arbogast also handed the officer the title to his car and a promissory note in exchange for a half-pound bag of marijuana.Â  The sheriffâ€™s department recorded the entire exchange on video and audio equipment.Â  Upon Arbogastâ€™s immediate arrest, officers discovered another bottle of opium and several more pill bottles in Arbogastâ€™s car, as well as the half-pound bag of marijuana sold to him by the undercover officer.Â  
Arbogast was indicted for trafficking in opium, distribution of Tylenol Four with codeine, and distribution of marijuana.Â  At trial, Arbogast presented evidence that he legally obtained the opium and Tylenol through prescriptions for a serious health condition.Â  Though Arbogast admitted he sold the drugs to the undercover officer on March 26, 2002, he testified to numerous occasions when the informant requested drugs, but he would not provide them.Â  Arbogast also claimed he â€œsure didnâ€™t think [he] was selling as much [opium] as he didâ€ that day.Â  He â€œthought [he] was selling maybe 10 millimeters of opium.â€Â  At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, the trial court granted Arbogastâ€™s motion to dismiss the indictment on distribution of marijuana.Â  Arbogast made no other motions at that time.Â  Following the close of the defenseâ€™s case, Arbogast requested a charge on entrapment, which was granted.Â  Arbogast made no other motions prior to the trial courtâ€™s charge to the jury.Â  Following the jury charge, Arbogast made a motion for a directed verdict because the indictment incorrectly referred to opium as a schedule one controlled substance, instead of a schedule two, as required by section 44-53-210(b)(1) of the South Carolina Code (2002).Â  The State then made a motion to amend the indictment to reflect opium as a scheduled two controlled substance.Â  The trial court denied both motions and submitted all evidence to the jury.Â  
The jury found Arbogast guilty of both charges, and the trial court sentenced him to twenty-five years for trafficking in opium and five years concurrent for distribution of Tylenol Four with codeine.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only and is bound by factual findings of the trial court unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  A trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The appellate court should examine the record to determine whether there is any evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  If there is any evidence in the record, the appellate court should affirm.Â  Id.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Arbogast claims the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict because the indictment incorrectly cited opium as a schedule one controlled substance.Â  We disagree. 
We find the motion regarding sufficiency of the indictment to be improperly raised, particularly because Arbogast failed to raise an objection before the jury was sworn as required by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 103, 610 S.E.2d 494, 500 (2005) (â€œBecause Appellant did not raise the sufficiency of the indictments before the jury was sworn, he cannot now raise this issue on appeal.â€).Â  Furthermore, Arbogast failed to move for a directed verdict at the end of the Stateâ€™s case or his own.Â  See State v. Rosemond, 348 S.C. 621, 627, 560 S.E.2d 636, 639-40 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Therefore, this issue was not preserved for our review.Â  However, we will address this issue on its merits. 
In ruling on motions for a directed verdict, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions and to deny the motions when either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003).Â  When considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 308, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002).Â  â€œIn essence, we must determine whether a verdict for a party opposing the motion would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.â€ Bultman v. Barber, 277 S.C. 5, 7, 281 S.E.2d 791, 792 (1981).Â  â€œIf the evidence is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, the case should be submitted to the jury.â€Â  Quesinberry v. Rouppasong, 331 S.C. 589, 594, 503 S.E.2d 717, 720 (1998).
A defendant must be convicted of the particular offense charged in the indictment.Â  State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75, 79 (1993).Â  A material variance between the charge and the proof entitles the defendant to a directed verdict.Â  Id.Â  However, a variance is not material â€œwhere the matter alleged is not an element of the offense.â€Â  State v. Hiott, 276 S.C. 72, 81, 276 S.E.2d 163, 167 (1981).Â  Moreover, when an indictment contains matters unnecessary to the description of the offense, the unnecessary language may be disregarded as surplusage, and no proof thereof is required.Â  State v. Thompson, 305 S.C. 496, 501 n.1, 409 S.E.2d 420, 423 n.1 (Ct. App. 1991).Â Â Â  
Following the trial courtâ€™s jury charge, Arbogast made a motion for a directed verdict because the indictment charged Arbogast with â€œknowingly sell[ing] . . . more than (28) twenty-eight grams of Opium, a scheduled I controlled substance.â€ (emphasis added).Â  According to section 44-53-210(b)(1) of the South Carolina Code (2002), opium is a scheduled II controlled substance.Â  This, however, is not an essential element of the offense of trafficking in opium.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(e)(3)(c) (2002 and Supp. 2004).Â  Section 44-53-370(e)(3)(c) states the following:

  Any person who knowingly sells, manufactures, cultivates, delivers, purchases, or brings into this State, 
  . . .
  (3) four grams or more of any morphine, opium, salt, isomer, or salt of an isomer thereof, including heroin, . . . or four grams or more of any mixture containing any of these substances, is guilty of a felony which is known as â€œtrafficking in illegal drugsâ€ and, upon conviction, must beÂ  punished as follows if the quantity involved is: 
  . . .
  (c) twenty-eight grams or more, a mandatory term of imprisonment of not less than twenty-five years nor more than forty years, no part of which may be suspended nor probation granted, and a fine of two hundred thousand dollars.

Therefore, the language in the indictment regarding the schedule of narcotic involved was mere surplusage.Â  Thompson, 305 S.C. at 501 n.1, 409 S.E.2d at 423 n.1.Â  Designation of the schedule in which opium was listed in the statute was not necessary for the indictment to fully apprise Arbogast of the charges against him.Â  See State v. Lawrence, 264 S.C. 3, 12, 212 S.E.2d 52, 56 (1975) (â€œIt was unnecessary for the indictment to designate the schedule on which amphetamine was listed in order to fully apprise appellants of the charge against them.â€).Â Â Â  
Arbogast also asserts the following issues: (1) the trial court violated his due process rights by charging him with trafficking in opium, an illegal activity, even though he obtained the opium through legal prescriptions; (2) the trial court erred in charging the jury on the lesser-included offense of distribution of opium, but failed to provide the lesser-included offense as an optional sentence on the verdict form; and (3) the trial court erred in failing to instruct the jury that conviction of the offense of trafficking in cocaine required Arbogast to knowingly sell more than four grams of opium.Â  
â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilkie, 330 S.C. 71, 75, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â  Contemporaneous objection is required to properly preserve error for appellate review.Â  State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 41, 476 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996).Â  Issues not raised to and ruled upon by the trial court are not properly preserved for appeal.Â  State v. Williams, 303 S.C. 410, 411, 401 S.E.2d 168, 169 (1991).Â Â Â  Arbogast failed to object to the jury charge and verdict forms at trial.Â  Therefore, these issues were not preserved for our review.Â  
CONCLUSION
Because the variance between the charge and the proof presented at trial was not material, and the other issues were not preserved, the trial courtâ€™s decision is hereby

text:
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Donna A. Green, Employee, Claimant, Appellant,
v.
GKN Automotive, Employer, and Zurich American, Carrier, Defendants,
Of whom GKN Automotive is the, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-566
Submitted October 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 26, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Marvin Mullis, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
William Lee Duda, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Donna A. Green appeals the denial of her request for workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  The single commissioner and appellate panel of the commission (the Commission) found Green failed to sustain her burden of proving her claimed injury was causally related to her employment.Â  The decision was affirmed by the circuit court.Â  We also affirm.[1]
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Claimant Donna A. Green was employed by Respondent GKN Automotive as an assembly line worker in the companyâ€™s Columbia automotive parts factory.Â  Green had worked for GKN for approximately two years when, on February 7, 2002, she claims she was injured on the job.Â  In her testimony before the single commissioner, Green described what she was doing on February 7 and how she was purportedly injured.Â  She testified that she had been given a new job assignment that day working on a â€œGMX 320â€ machine performing â€œoperations 30 and 40,â€ tasks Green asserted were not her regularly assigned work.Â  These â€œoperationsâ€ required Green to assemble steel automobile prop shafts.Â  When assembled, these prop shafts were roughly seven feet in length and each weighed about 20 pounds.Â  Green was then required to hang each of the finished shafts on a rack approximately seven feet tall.Â  Green claimed that, because of her height (about five feet, two inches tall), she had to lift the assembled prop shafts above her head and shoulders, stretch, and stand on the tips of her toes in order to place shafts on the rack.Â  Green claimed this exertion caused her great strain, resulting in â€œmuscle spasmsâ€ down her left and right side.Â  She testified that she also began to feel pain and numbness in her arms during her hour-long drive home on the evening of February 7.Â  
When Green returned to the factory the next morning, she claimed the pain and numbness she experienced the night before continued and became more severe as she began her dayâ€™s work.Â  She reported the problem to her supervisor and the safety officer at the factory who sent her to Providence Occupational Health Services for examination.Â  Green was examined by Dr. Richard Boyer, who determined she was suffering from Paresthesia, or a tingling sensation, in her left arm.Â  He prescribed heat and ibuprofen to reduce the discomfort, and found she was fit to return to work without any restrictions on her activities.Â  
Green continued working normal hours until February 25, 2002, when she visited her personal physician complaining of continued upper body pain and numbness.Â  Greenâ€™s doctor examined her and determined she should be excused from work and that she should be treated with a regimen of physical therapy.Â  Green followed her doctorâ€™s adviceâ€”leaving work and attending regular therapy.Â  After several months of treatment, Green returned to work in May 2002, but she was only able to work one week.Â  Shortly thereafter, Green filed a Form 50 seeking temporary total disability benefits. 
At the hearing before the single commissioner, it was brought to light that Green had offered vague and contradictory reports to her employer concerning how she was injured.Â  A critical inconsistency was discovered in a â€œPersonal Injury Reportâ€ Green had filled out and submitted to GKN on February 8, 2002, the day after her alleged injury at the factory.Â  In this report, Green indicated that she was injured while performing â€œoperation 50â€ which she further indicated was her â€œregularly assigned workâ€â€”not the new, unfamiliar work of â€œoperations 30 and 40â€ on the â€œGMX 320â€ machine as she testified to before the single commissioner.Â  Green also wrote in this report that the injury occurred because the â€œpedestal wheel [was] too tightâ€â€”again, contrary to her testimony that she was injured while attempting to lift the steel prop shafts onto a rack.Â  Green also acknowledged that when she initially reported her injury to the factory safety officer and her supervisor, she was unable to tell either person exactly how she was injured.Â  
Another inconsistency was discovered in a form requesting short-term disability benefits Green had filled out and submitted to GKNâ€™s insurance carrier in March 2002.Â  This form required Green to describe the physical ailment that was preventing her from working, and specifically asked: â€œIs this condition work related?â€ and â€œIf Yes, do you intend to file a Workersâ€™ Compensation claim?â€Â  Green did not answer either of these two questions, leaving that portion of the form blank.Â  
Further questions were raised concerning similar inconsistencies reflected in the medical reports prepared by Greenâ€™s treating physicians.Â  For example, Dr. Boyer, the first doctor Green visited the day after her claimed injury, reported that Green complained of pain in her left arm, with no mention made of any other part of her body.Â  However, the report prepared by Greenâ€™s personal physician after her examination two weeks later indicates that her pain started in her right arm.Â Â  
After the hearing, the single commissioner entered an order denying Greenâ€™s request for workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  In reaching this decision, the single commissioner noted the material inconsistencies in how Green reported her alleged injury to her employer and treating physicians.Â  The commissioner found that Green was unable to recall any specific incident that resulted in her injury, noting that she could not tell her GKN supervisor or the safety specialist how she was injured, nor could she provide this basic information to Dr. Boyer.Â  The commissioner also found that Green failed to indicate that her injuries were work-related when she applied for short-term disability benefits.Â  Based on these findings, the commissioner concluded Green had not met her burden of proving she had suffered an â€œaccidentâ€ or â€œinjuryâ€ as those terms are defined under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act or that the physical ailments she claimed to have suffered were causally related to her employment.Â Â  
Green appealed the single commissionerâ€™s order to the Commission, arguing the single commissioner erred in failing to find she had suffered a â€œrepetitive trauma injury.â€Â  The Commission denied the appeal and adopted the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  Subsequent appeal was taken to the circuit court which was also denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 133-34, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305-06 (1981).Â  Under the APA, our scope of review is limited to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 84, 610 S.E.2d 488, 490 (2005); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).
The findings of the Commission will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 492, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001).Â  As our courts have repeatedly held, substantial evidence is not a â€œmere scintilla of evidence,â€ nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004).Â  The Commission is the ultimate fact finder and the final arbiter of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence.Â  See Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 67, 456 S.E.2d 366, 368 (1995).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
In this appeal, Green asserts both legal and factual error with regard to the Commissionâ€™s ruling that she failed to prove a compensable injury occurred.Â  Specifically, she argues the Commission applied the wrong legal standard for determining causation in this case and that, in any event, the Commissionâ€™s ruling is unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree, finding the Commission applied the proper legal standard and that its ruling is amply supported by substantial evidence.
For an injury to be compensable under our workersâ€™ compensation laws, an employee must show that her injury arose â€œout ofâ€ and â€œin the course of employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2003).Â  â€œAn injury arises out of employment when there is apparent to the rational mind, upon consideration of all the circumstances, a causal relationship between the conditions under which the work is to be performed and the resulting injury.â€Â  Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 518, 466 S.E.2d 357, 358 (1996) (quoting Owings v. Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 315 S.C. 297, 299, 433 S.E.2d 869, 871 (1993)).Â  
Green correctly points out that our supreme court has ruled that repetitive events causing trauma to a worker in the course of employment may be found compensable as â€œaccidentsâ€ or â€œinjuriesâ€ under the Act.Â  See Pee v. AVM, Inc., 352 S.C. 167, 174, 573 S.E.2d 785, 789 (2002) (holding that a repetitive trauma injury meets the definition of â€œinjury by accidentâ€ under the Act in that it is an unforeseen injury caused by trauma).Â  â€œRepetitive trauma injuries . . . have a gradual onset caused by the cumulative effect of repetitive traumatic events or â€˜mini-accidents.â€™â€Â  Schulknight v. City of North Charleston, 352 S.C. 175, 178, 574 S.E.2d 194, 195 (2002).
As the claimant in this case, Green bore the burden of proving such facts as to render her injury compensable under the Act, and we recognize the Commission was under a concomitant obligation to enter specific findings based on its review of the record.Â  Shealy v. Algernon Blair, Inc., 250 S.C. 106, 109-10, 156 S.E.2d 646, 648 (1967).
In the present case, the Commissionâ€”in adopting the order of the single commissionerâ€”did not enter any specific findings or otherwise opine on the question of whether Green suffered a compensable â€œrepetitive traumaâ€ injury, and there was no reason for the Commission to do so.Â  Green proceeded on the basis that her claimed injury occurred as a result of one distinct incidentâ€”a single dayâ€™s work assembling the steel prop shafts on February 7, 2002, away from her regularly assigned duties.[2]Â  The claim was not presented as one involving a repetitive trauma.Â  We find Greenâ€™s suggestion that this is a repetitive trauma case to be incongruous with the facts in the record before us.Â  In any event, in light of the critical inconsistencies in Greenâ€™s case and the Commissionâ€™s role in assessing credibility, there is substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s determination that Green failed to establish a work related injury, be it a repetitive trauma injury or otherwise.[3]  
CONCLUSION
We conclude the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission applied the correct legal standard and that its determination finds substantial evidentiary support in the record.Â  The order of the Commission finding Donna Green was not entitled to workersâ€™ compensation benefits is 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ. concur.

[1]Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215,
SCACR.
 [2]  Indeed, both parties stipulated in proceedings before the single commissioner that â€œ[t]he date of Claimantâ€™s alleged injury is February 7, 2002.â€ 
[3]Â Â  Green maintains that all of the inconsistencies in her various accounts can be attributed to faulty recollection or mistake by herself or others.Â  To be sure, Greenâ€™s attempts to explain these evidentiary problems may be credible.Â  However, such determinations go to the heart of assessing witness credibility and the weight to be assigned to the testimonyâ€”matters exclusively within the province of the Commission.Â  See Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 67, 456 S.E.2d 366, 368 (1995) (noting that the final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Commission); see also Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999) (noting that â€œ[t]he possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent the Commissionâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidenceâ€).Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-571
Submitted October 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 27, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Edward Bradley and Katherine Carruth Link, both of West Columbia, for Appellants.Â  
Christa Tidwell Bell, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John and Nancy Dowling appeal the zoning boardâ€™s determination that their property lost its grandfathered status due to a change in use from a boarding house to a residential care facility.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
The Dowlings own property at 2906 River Drive in Columbia.Â  Prior to the area being zoned, the Dowlings were operating a boarding house at the location.Â  The current zoning, RG-1 (general resident district), went into effect in 1981, and the Dowlings applied for and received a certificate of non-compliance from the City of Columbia to allow the continued operation of their boarding house.Â  In 1982, the Dowlings applied for and were granted a license from the Department of Health and Environmental Control to operate the property as a residential care facility.Â  They operated the residential care facility on the property until 2000, at which time they resumed operation as a boarding house.Â  
After receiving complaints about the operation of the boarding house, the Cityâ€™s zoning office conducted an inspection and investigation that revealed the DHEC license had expired and resumption of use of the premises as a boarding house violated zoning regulations.Â  The Dowlings were told to stop operation of the boarding house, or they would be fined for violation of the Cityâ€™s zoning ordinances.Â  The Dowlingsâ€™ appeal was denied by the Cityâ€™s Zoning Board of Adjustments, and the circuit court affirmed.Â  The Dowlings now appeal to this court.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the issues on appeal, the court shall only determine whether the decision of the board is correct as a matter of law, and the boardâ€™s decision will not be overturned on appeal unless it is arbitrary, capricious, has no reasonable relation to a lawful purpose, or if the board has abused its discretion.Â  Austin v. Bd. of Zoning Appeals, 362 S.C. 29, 33, 606 S.E.2d 209, 211 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An appellate court is to give â€œsubstantial deference to the decisions of those charged with interpreting and applying local zoning ordinances.â€Â  Clear Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach, 360 S.C. 459, 465, 602 S.E.2d 76, 79 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
 

Section 17-202(e) of the City of Columbia Code of
Ordinances provides that â€œ[a] non-conforming use or characteristic of use
shall not be reestablished after vacancy, abandonment, or discontinuance for any
period of 12 consecutive months.â€  

Columbia
, 
S.C.

, Code Â§ 17-202(e) (1998).  The
Dowlings contend they never discontinued operating a boarding house, and they
could not, therefore, have forfeited their right to operate a boarding house
pursuant to the 1981 certificate of non-compliance. 
They contend that a residential care facility is simply a specialized
type of boarding house, and the Board erred in finding otherwise. 
We disagree.  
  The Dowlings argue that a â€œcommunity residential care facilityâ€ is included within the definition of â€œboarding houseâ€ as found in the Cityâ€™s Code.[2]Â  However, the record shows that â€œcommunity residential care facilityâ€ is separately defined in the code and emphasizes that its residents, unlike residents of a boarding house, require a degree of â€œpersonal assistance.â€[3]Â  The record further shows that boarding houses are specifically excluded from RG-1 zoning while a facility such as the one operated by the Dowlings pursuant to their DHEC license is exempt from zoning under State law.[4]Â  Finally, boarding house and community care facilities have separate classifications in the SIC, a standardized industrial coding system adopted by the City for use in zoning.Â  Consequently, there is ample evidence in the record to support the Boardâ€™s conclusion that a boarding house and a residential care facility are two distinct types of uses for property.Â  
  The Dowlings further argue that the City is estopped from claiming that the residential care facility was not concurrently a boarding house, because the City issued business licenses to the Dowlings for the operation of a boarding house from 1976 through 2001.Â  However, according to the Cityâ€™s Zoning Administrator, classifications within the licensing division are fee-based and involve more generalized categories.Â  Furthermore, the only time the zoning department approves of the license is upon the initial issuance.Â  After that, the renewal of a license is more or less a routine matter of paperwork and the payment of fees.Â  There is no evidence in the record to suggest the City considered the residential care facility to constitute a boarding house for zoning purposes.
  Finally, the Dowlings argue that the character of their property never changed, and the board erred in holding that they failed to produce any evidence to support such a contention.Â  Again, we disagree.Â  It was incumbent upon the Dowlings to present evidence showing that the character of their property did not change.Â  However, there was no testimony or other evidence presented to that effect.Â  The Dowlings relied on the Cityâ€™s awarding of the business licenses and the definitions in the code to make their case.Â  Those items do nothing to elucidate how the property was used by the Dowlings and therefore cannot support an argument that the character of the property remained unchanged.Â  
  For all of the foregoing reasons, we conclude the decision of the board was not arbitrary, capricious, or unreasonable.Â  Therefore, the decision of the circuit court is
  AFFIRMED.
  HEARN, C.J., STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  A â€œrooming houseâ€ or â€œboarding houseâ€ is â€œany dwelling, other than a hotel or motel, in which more than three persons who are not members of the ownerâ€™s or operatorâ€™s family are housed or lodged in rooms used or intended to be used for living and sleeping but not for cooking or eating purposes, for compensation . . . .â€Â  Columbia, S.C., Code Â§ 17-55 (1998).
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  â€œCommunity residential care facility includes any institution, place, building or agency providing for a period exceeding 24 consecutive hours accommodation, board, and a degree of personal assistance in feeding, dressing or other essential daily living activities to two or more individuals not related to the administrator or owner . . . .â€Â  Columbia, S.C., Code Â§ 17-55 (1998).
[4] Â Â Â Â Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§6-29-770(E) (2004) provides that â€œa home serving nine or fewer mentally or physically handicapped persons provided the home provides care on a twenty-four hour basis and is approved or licensed by a state agency or department or under contract with the agency or department for that purposeâ€ is not subject to the zoning ordinance.

PER CURIAM:Â  Geraldine Daniels applied for workersâ€™ compensation benefits alleging a change in physical condition.Â  The single commissioner, commission, and circuit court found Daniels sustained a change in condition for the worse, entitling her to payment of medical expenses and temporary total disability benefits.Â  Bi-Lo, as Danielsâ€™ former employer, and its carrier (collectively â€œBi-Loâ€) appeal.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In April of 2001, Daniels sustained an injury while working for Bi-Lo.Â  By order dated December 13, 2002, the single commissioner found the injury compensable.Â  Bi-Lo appealed the commissionerâ€™s order to the full commission.Â  While the appeal was pending, Daniels applied for additional benefits, alleging she sustained a compensable change in condition.Â  
For her initial injury, Daniels received medical care from Drs. Young and Poletti.Â  At that time, based on a 2001 MRI performed on Daniels, Dr. Young concluded that Daniels suffered â€œ[m]oderate to moderately severe degenerative disc/osteophyte disease . . . .â€ Â Dr. Poletti likewise examined the 2001 MRI and found Daniels would be a candidate for surgery but recommended against it because Daniels was experiencing unusual symptoms including blurred vision and ringing in her ears.Â  
In 2003, Daniels allegedly suffered a change in condition for the worse and sought treatment from Dr. Giddens.Â  Dr. Giddens ordered another MRI.Â  Dr. Giddens â€œdiscussed performing anterior cervical discectomy and fusion . . . based upon an MRI scan demonstrating significant disc herniation . . . [and] also noted . . . that [Danielsâ€™] disc herniation was the likely culprit for her . . . symptoms.â€[2]Â  By letter dated January 20, 2004, Dr. Giddens conceded he could not â€œanswer . . . questions regarding whether or not [Danielsâ€™] condition was worsened . . . .â€Â  He stated, however, that Daniels reported increased pain and a worsened condition, and he recommended surgery.Â  
Dr. Young reviewed the 2003 MRI and found no change in condition.Â  Dr. Poletti also found no change in condition.Â  However, he agreed with Dr. Giddens that Daniels was now a surgical candidate and further opined that surgery could relieve some of Danielsâ€™ pain.Â  
At the hearing before the single commissioner, Daniels testified that her pain had worsened since the initial award.Â  She explained:Â  â€œThe pain is longer, the pain is more, it comes on me more than it did.â€ Â Daniels also relied on the opinion of Dr. Giddens.Â  Bi-Lo relied on the opinions of Drs. Young and Poletti.Â  
The single commissioner concluded Daniels sustained a change in physical condition for the worse and ordered Bi-Lo to compensate Daniels for medical expenses and temporary total disability.Â  Both an appellate panel of the commission and the circuit court affirmed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of whether a claimant experiences a change in condition
is a question for the fact finder.Â  Krell v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 237 S.C. 584, 588, 118 S.E.2d 322, 323-24 (1961).Â  The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the substantial evidence standard of review for factual findings made by the commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 133, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1981).Â  Under the substantial evidence standard of review, this court may reverse the commissionâ€™s findings only when they are unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  â€œâ€˜Substantial evidenceâ€™ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€Â  Lark, 276 S.C. at 135, 276 S.E.2d at 306.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 
    Bi-Lo argues there was neither medical evidence nor claimant testimony supporting the finding that Daniels sustained a change in condition for the worse.[3]Â  We disagree.Â  A change in condition occurs when the claimant experiences a change in physical condition as a result of the original injury, after the initial award.Â  Gattis v. Murrells Inlet VFW #10420, 353 S.C. 100, 109, 576 S.E.2d 191, 196 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The commission may consider lay testimony and medical evidence in determining if a claimant has suffered a change in condition.Â  Lloyd v. AT&T Nassau Metals Corp., 299 S.C. 207, 208, 383 S.E.2d 257, 258 (Ct. App. 1989). 
    The commissioner found Dr. Giddens more credible than Dr. Poletti in part because Dr. Poletti expressed an opinion that there was no change in condition but conceded that surgery could now relieve some of Danielsâ€™ pain.Â  The commissioner further found Daniels to be credible.Â  The commission adopted these findings, and the circuit court affirmed.Â  Applying the substantial evidence rule of appellate review, as we must, we find evidence to support these findings.Â  
    CONCLUSION
    For the foregoing reasons, the order on appeal is
     AFFIRMED.
    HEARN, C.J., STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
    
    [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
    [2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Although Dr. Giddensâ€™ records are not included in the record on appeal, his findings are summarized by the commissioner.Â  Bi-Lo does not challenge the commissionerâ€™s summarization.Â  
    [3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Although Bi-Lo lists three issues on appeal, it essentially raises only one issue:Â  whether there is error in the finding of a change in condition.Â

Heard October 5, 2005 â€“ Filed October 28, 2005Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, of Columbia; and Solicitor David Michael Pascoe, Jr., of St. Matthews, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Timothy Phillips appeals his convictions for assault and battery with intent to kill, possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime, and injuring or disabling a police dog.Â  We affirm.
On the evening of April 6, 2003, an altercation erupted between Timothy Phillips and his 14-year-old stepson Jeffrey, resulting in Jeffrey calling 911. Â Ashley, Phillipsâ€™s wife, intervened in the conflict, and the couple began fighting. Â Jeffrey left the house during the fight. Â 
Ashley missed Jeffrey once the fight ended and ran outside to look for him.Â  Phillips followed after to help look for Jeffrey and brought a shotgun.[1]Â  Ashley encountered Deputy Michael Deese, who had been dispatched to answer the 911 call. Â Ashley told Deese her son was missing, Phillips was armed, the situation was serious, and Phillips was going to kill her. Â While they talked, Phillips approached and pointed his shotgun in the direction of Deese, who had remained in his vehicle. Â 
Deese ordered Phillips to drop the shotgun several times and drew his own weapon. Â A firefight ensued, resulting in Phillips wounding Deese and the police dog in his vehicle.[2] Â Ashley ran to the nearby home of Jennifer Johnson[3] when the shooting began.Â  Phillips was arrested at his home and subsequently convicted of the charges noted above. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â Â Phillips argues the trial judge erred by refusing to give specific answers requested by the defense in response to the juryâ€™s questions. Â We disagree.
â€œIn reviewing jury charges for error, we must consider the courtâ€™s jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.â€Â  State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 318, 577 S.E.2d 460, 463 (Ct. App. 2003). Â â€œJury instructions should be considered as a whole, and if as a whole they are free from error, any isolated portions which may be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  State v. Buckner, 341 S.C. 241, 246-47, 534 S.E.2d 15, 18 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œTo warrant reversal, a trial judgeâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.â€Â  State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 106, 610 S.E.2d 859, 865 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
In a note, the jury asked the trial judge two questions regarding the jury instructions on assault and battery with intent to kill.Â  The first asked, â€œIf the defendant is found guilty of assault and battery with a shotgun, is that automatic intent to kill?â€Â  The second question was, â€œDoes assault and battery with a deadly weapon constitute intent to kill?â€Â  The defense asked the judge to specifically answer the questions.Â  
The trial judge declined to do so, reasoning it would be a charge on the facts and an invasion of the juryâ€™s role to make factual determinations in the case.Â  See S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 21 (â€œJudges shall not charge juries in respect to matters of fact, but shall declare the law.â€); State v. Bagwell, 201 S.C. 387, 399, 23 S.E.2d 244, 249 (1942) (â€œA [j]udge cannot express in his charge, or intimate any opinion as to the weight or the sufficiency of testimony . . . without violating the prohibition of the Constitution as to charging upon the facts.â€).
The trial judge also felt the questions too complex to be answered either â€œyesâ€ or â€œno.â€ Â He reiterated large portions of his original instructions to the jury with the expectation it would answer the juryâ€™s questions.[4] Â See Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 53, 557 S.E.2d 676, 686 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œIt is not error to refuse a request to charge when the substance of the request is included in the general instructions.â€); State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 261, 565 S.E.2d 298, 303 (2002) (â€œThe substance of the law must be charged to the jury, not particular verbiage.â€).
After reviewing the record, we find the charge contained all of the applicable legal principles for the jury to make its determination.Â  The trial judge adequately addressed the juryâ€™s questions without intruding upon the juryâ€™s role as the ultimate finder of fact.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s charge, considered as a whole, was appropriate and does not constitute error.Â  
2.Â Phillips next argues the trial judge erred in limiting the defenseâ€™s cross-examination of Jennifer Johnson concerning statements allegedly made by Phillipsâ€™s wife, Ashley.Â  
â€œOur courts have consistently held that the scope and extent of cross-examination is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€ Â State v. Sierra, 337 S.C. 368, 373, 523 S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œThis court will not disturb the trial judgeâ€™s decision unless appellant shows both prejudice and an abuse of discretion.â€ Â Id. Â 
Johnson testified she heard gunshots and then saw Ashley come into her yard within minutes of the shooting.Â  Johnson, who did not know Ashley at the time of the incident, testified Ashley â€œsaid that her husband just shot a cop, she thought he killed him, and that he was now after her and she [was] just looking for a place to hide and she just wanted to hide there.â€Â  The trial judge allowed this into evidence under the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule. Â 
On cross-examination, Phillips sought to ask Johnson if in her written statement to the police she said Ashley told her:Â  (1) Ashley had called the police, (2) the police came to the Phillipsesâ€™ home, and (3) Phillips appeared from the side of the Phillipsesâ€™ home and shot at the police vehicle. Â The State objected on the ground that Johnsonâ€™s prior statement was inadmissible unless inconsistent with her testimony in court.Â
